Additionally, we will sometimes use the notation Qâ¢(x,Ï€)ğ‘„ğ‘¥ğœ‹Q\left(x,\pi\right)italic_Q ( italic_x , italic_Ï€ ) to denote âˆ‘aÏ€(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)Q(x,a)\sum_{a}\pi\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)% Q\left(x,a\right)âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ ( italic_a | italic_x ) italic_Q ( italic_x , italic_a ) for any policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ and any function Q:ğ’³Ã—ğ’œâ†’â„:ğ‘„â†’ğ’³ğ’œâ„Q\colon\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}\to\mathbb{R}italic_Q : caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_A â†’ blackboard_R. Note that this notation allows us to write VÏ€â¢(x)=QÏ€â¢(x,Ï€)superscriptğ‘‰ğœ‹ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹ğ‘¥ğœ‹V^{\pi}\left(x\right)=Q^{\pi}\left(x,\pi\right)italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_Ï€ ). Any policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ induces an occupancy measure Î¼Ï€âˆˆÎ”â¢(ğ’³Ã—ğ’œ)superscriptğœ‡ğœ‹Î”ğ’³ğ’œ\mu^{\pi}\in\Delta\left(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}\right)italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î” ( caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_A ) over state-action pairs, defined as the discounted total expected times that each state-action pair is visited by policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€. The same quantity defined for states is called the state-occupancy measure and is denoted as Î½Ï€âˆˆÎ”â¢(ğ’³)superscriptğœˆğœ‹Î”ğ’³\nu^{\pi}\in\Delta\left(\mathcal{X}\right)italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î” ( caligraphic_X ). For any state-action pair (x,a)âˆˆğ’³Ã—ğ’œğ‘¥ğ‘ğ’³ğ’œ\left(x,a\right)\in\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}( italic_x , italic_a ) âˆˆ caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_A, they are respectively defined as

Î½Ï€â¢(x)=(1âˆ’Î³)â¢âˆ‘h=0âˆÎ³hâ¢â„™Ï€â¢[Xh=x],andÎ¼Ï€â¢(x,a)=(1âˆ’Î³)â¢âˆ‘h=0âˆÎ³hâ¢â„™Ï€â¢[Xh=x,Ah=a],formulae-sequencesuperscriptğœˆğœ‹ğ‘¥1ğ›¾subscriptsuperscriptâ„0superscriptğ›¾â„superscriptâ„™ğœ‹delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‹â„ğ‘¥andsuperscriptğœ‡ğœ‹ğ‘¥ğ‘1ğ›¾subscriptsuperscriptâ„0superscriptğ›¾â„superscriptâ„™ğœ‹delimited-[]formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‹â„ğ‘¥subscriptğ´â„ğ‘\nu^{\pi}\left(x\right)=\left(1-\gamma\right)\sum^{\infty}_{h=0}\gamma^{h}% \mathbb{P}^{\pi}\left[X_{h}=x\right]\,,\quad\text{and}\quad\mu^{\pi}\left(x,a% \right)=\left(1-\gamma\right)\sum^{\infty}_{h=0}\gamma^{h}\mathbb{P}^{\pi}% \left[X_{h}=x,A_{h}=a\right]\,,italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x ] , and italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) = ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a ] ,

and they are related to each other by the flow conditions (sometimes called â€œBellman flow conditionsâ€)

Î½Ï€(x)=Î³âˆ‘xâ€²,aâ€²P(x\nonscript|\nonscriptxâ€²,aâ€²)Î¼Ï€(xâ€²,aâ€²)+(1âˆ’Î³)Î½0(x).\nu^{\pi}\left(x\right)=\gamma\sum_{x^{\prime},a^{\prime}}P\left(x\nonscript% \mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x^{\prime},a^{\prime}\right)\mu^{\pi% }\left(x^{\prime},a^{\prime}\right)+\left(1-\gamma\right)\nu_{0}\left(x\right)\,.italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_Î³ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_x | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) . (1)

Notably, these definitions and the flow conditions remain valid for general history-dependent policies Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ that may take the entire history of state-action pairs (X1,A1,â€¦,Xh)subscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ´1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹â„\left(X_{1},A_{1},\dots,X_{h}\right)( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) into account when selecting each action Ahsubscriptğ´â„A_{h}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Finally, we let ÏÏ€=ğ”¼Ï€â¢[âˆ‘h=0âˆÎ³hâ¢râ¢(Xh,Ah)]superscriptğœŒğœ‹superscriptğ”¼ğœ‹delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptâ„0superscriptğ›¾â„ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘‹â„subscriptğ´â„\rho^{\pi}=\mathbb{E}^{\pi}\left[\sum_{h=0}^{\infty}\gamma^{h}r\left(X_{h},A_{% h}\right)\right]italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] stand for the total expected return of a (potentially nonstationary) policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€. The following useful result, commonly called the performance-difference lemma (Kakade and Langford 2002, see also Eq.Â 7.14 in Howard 1960), gives a useful expression for the performance gap between two policies.

Lemma 1.

Let Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ be a stationary policy and Ï€â€²superscriptğœ‹â€²\pi^{\prime}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be any policy. Then,

ÏÏ€â€²âˆ’ÏÏ€=ğ”¼(X,A)âˆ¼Î¼Ï€â€²â¢[QÏ€â¢(X,A)âˆ’VÏ€â¢(X)].superscriptğœŒsuperscriptğœ‹â€²superscriptğœŒğœ‹subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘‹ğ´superscriptğœ‡superscriptğœ‹â€²delimited-[]superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹ğ‘‹ğ´superscriptğ‘‰ğœ‹ğ‘‹\rho^{\pi^{\prime}}-\rho^{\pi}=\mathbb{E}_{\left(X,A\right)\sim\mu^{\pi^{% \prime}}}\left[Q^{\pi}\left(X,A\right)-V^{\pi}\left(X\right)\right]\,.italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X , italic_A ) âˆ¼ italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_X , italic_A ) - italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_X ) ] .

Note that this lemma is generally stated for stationary policies, but we will find it useful later to use it with general history-dependent policies. We provide the straightforward proof in AppendixÂ B.1.

Imitation Learning.

We consider the problem of offline imitation learning. Given a dataset ğ’ŸÏ€E={XEi,AEi}i=1Ï„Esuperscriptğ’Ÿsubscriptğœ‹Esubscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‹Eğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ´Eğ‘–subscriptğœEğ‘–1\mathcal{D}^{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}=\left\{X_{\scriptscriptstyle% \textup{E}}^{i},A_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i}\right\}^{\tau_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}_{i=1}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of state-action pairs sampled from an expert policyâ€™s occupancy measure Î¼Ï€Esuperscriptğœ‡subscriptğœ‹E\mu^{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, our objective is to design an algorithm, AlgAlg\mathrm{Alg}roman_Alg, that produces a policy Ï€outsuperscriptğœ‹out\pi^{\mathrm{out}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfying

ğ”¼â¢[ÏÏ€Eâˆ’ÏÏ€out]â‰¤Îµ.ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğœŒsubscriptğœ‹EsuperscriptğœŒsuperscriptğœ‹outğœ€\mathbb{E}\left[\rho^{{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}-\rho^{\pi^{\mathrm% {out}}}\right]\leq\varepsilon\,.blackboard_E [ italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ italic_Îµ . (2)

The algorithm is not allowed any further interaction with the expert policy or the MDP â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M and only has to work with the record of state-action pairs contained in the data set. As stated in the introduction, we aim to achieve this without imposing expert realizability. Instead, we consider the following structural assumption on the environment.

Assumption 1 (Linear QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizability).

The action value function of any policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ can be written as a linear combination of known features. That is, there exists a known mapping Ï†:ğ’³Ã—ğ’œâ†’â„d:ğœ‘â†’ğ’³ğ’œsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\varphi:\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_Ï† : caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_A â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that for any policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€, there exists a vector Î¸Ï€âˆˆâ„dsuperscriptğœƒğœ‹superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\theta^{\pi}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that for any state-action pair (x,a)ğ‘¥ğ‘\left(x,a\right)( italic_x , italic_a ), QÏ€â¢(x,a)=âŸ¨Ï†â¢(x,a),Î¸Ï€âŸ©superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹ğ‘¥ğ‘ğœ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘superscriptğœƒğœ‹Q^{\pi}\left(x,a\right)=\left\langle\varphi\left(x,a\right),\theta^{\pi}\right\rangleitalic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) = âŸ¨ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_a ) , italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ©. Moreover, we assume â€–Î¸Ï€â€–â‰¤BÎ¸normsuperscriptğœƒğœ‹subscriptğµğœƒ\left\|{\theta^{\pi}}\right\|\leq B_{\theta}âˆ¥ italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€, and supx,aâ€–Ï†â¢(x,a)â€–â‰¤BÏ†subscriptsupremumğ‘¥ğ‘normğœ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptğµğœ‘\sup_{x,a}\left\|{\varphi\left(x,a\right)}\right\|\leq B_{\varphi}roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_a ) âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

We will also consider the general function approximation setting, where the action value function of any policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ can be represented by some function class ğ’¬âŠ‚â„ğ’³Ã—ğ’œğ’¬superscriptâ„ğ’³ğ’œ\mathcal{Q}\subset\mathbb{R}^{\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_Q âŠ‚ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Assumption 2 (QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizability).

An MDP is said QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable if there exists a function class ğ’¬âŠ‚â„ğ’³Ã—ğ’œğ’¬superscriptâ„ğ’³ğ’œ\mathcal{Q}\subset\mathbb{R}^{\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_Q âŠ‚ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that for any policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€, it holds that QÏ€âˆˆğ’¬superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹ğ’¬Q^{\pi}\in\mathcal{Q}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_Q, and for any Qâˆˆğ’¬ğ‘„ğ’¬Q\in\mathcal{Q}italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_Q, â€–Qâ€–âˆâ‰¤11âˆ’Î³subscriptnormğ‘„11ğ›¾\left\|{Q}\right\|_{\infty}\leq\frac{1}{1-\gamma}âˆ¥ italic_Q âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Î³ end_ARG.

For this assumption to make sense, we typically require the function class ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q to have bounded capacity. We quantify this via covering numbers, defined as follows.

Definition 1 (Covering number).

Let (M,d)ğ‘€ğ‘‘\left(M,d\right)( italic_M , italic_d ) be a metric space, Kğ¾Kitalic_K be a subset of Mğ‘€Mitalic_M, and Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0. A set ğ’Ïµâ¢(K,d)subscriptğ’italic-Ïµğ¾ğ‘‘\mathcal{C}_{\epsilon}\left(K,d\right)caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_K , italic_d ) is an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-covering of Kğ¾Kitalic_K if for any xâˆˆKğ‘¥ğ¾x\in Kitalic_x âˆˆ italic_K, there exists yâˆˆğ’Ïµâ¢(K,d)ğ‘¦subscriptğ’italic-Ïµğ¾ğ‘‘y\in\mathcal{C}_{\epsilon}\left(K,d\right)italic_y âˆˆ caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_K , italic_d ) such that dâ¢(x,y)â‰¤Ïµğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦italic-Ïµd\left(x,y\right)\leq\epsilonitalic_d ( italic_x , italic_y ) â‰¤ italic_Ïµ. The covering number of Kğ¾Kitalic_K, ğ’©Ïµâ¢(K,d)subscriptğ’©italic-Ïµğ¾ğ‘‘\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(K,d\right)caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_K , italic_d ), is the minimum cardinality of any such covering of Kğ¾Kitalic_K.

3 Primal-dual offline imitation learning

In order to introduce our main algorithmic idea, we define the following objective function:

â„’â¢(Ï€;Q)=ğ”¼(X,A)âˆ¼Î¼Ï€Eâ¢[Qâ¢(X,A)âˆ’Qâ¢(X,Ï€)],â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘‹ğ´superscriptğœ‡subscriptğœ‹Edelimited-[]ğ‘„ğ‘‹ğ´ğ‘„ğ‘‹ğœ‹\mathcal{L}\left(\pi;Q\right)=\mathbb{E}_{\left(X,A\right)\sim\mu^{{\pi_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}}\left[Q\left(X,A\right)-Q\left(X,\pi\right)% \right]\,,caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ ; italic_Q ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X , italic_A ) âˆ¼ italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Q ( italic_X , italic_A ) - italic_Q ( italic_X , italic_Ï€ ) ] ,

where we denoted Qâ¢(X,Ï€)=ğ”¼Aâ€²âˆ¼Ï€(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptX)â¢[Qâ¢(X,Aâ€²)]Q\left(X,\pi\right)=\mathbb{E}_{A^{\prime}\sim\pi\left(\cdot\nonscript% \mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}X\right)}\left[Q\left(X,A^{\prime}% \right)\right]italic_Q ( italic_X , italic_Ï€ ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Ï€ ( â‹… | italic_X ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Q ( italic_X , italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ]. Our main observation is that the main objective function we consider can be rewritten in terms of this function as follows:

ÏÏ€Eâˆ’ÏÏ€=â„’â¢(Ï€;QÏ€)â‰¤supQâˆˆğ’¬â„’â¢(Ï€;Q).superscriptğœŒsubscriptğœ‹EsuperscriptğœŒğœ‹â„’ğœ‹superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹subscriptsupremumğ‘„ğ’¬â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„\rho^{{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}-\rho^{\pi}=\mathcal{L}\left(\pi;Q^% {\pi}\right)\leq\textstyle\sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}}\mathcal{L}\left(\pi;Q\right).italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ ; italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ ; italic_Q ) .

This suggests a good policy Ï€outsuperscriptğœ‹out\pi^{\mathrm{out}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT may be found by solving the saddle-point optimization problem minÏ€â¢supQâˆˆğ’¬â„’â¢(Ï€;Q)subscriptğœ‹subscriptsupremumğ‘„ğ’¬â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„\min_{\pi}\sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}}\mathcal{L}\left(\pi;Q\right)roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ ; italic_Q ). Indeed, if one is able to produce a policy Ï€outsuperscriptğœ‹out\pi^{\mathrm{out}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfying supQâˆˆğ’¬â„’â¢(Ï€out;Q)â‰¤Îµsubscriptsupremumğ‘„ğ’¬â„’superscriptğœ‹outğ‘„ğœ€\sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}}\mathcal{L}\left(\pi^{\mathrm{out}};Q\right)\leq\varepsilonroman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Q ) â‰¤ italic_Îµ, then the above inequality implies that the suboptimality of Ï€outsuperscriptğœ‹out\pi^{\mathrm{out}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as compared to Ï€Esubscriptğœ‹E{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will also be at most Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ.

Inspired by this observation, we set out to design an incremental primal-dual optimization algorithm to approximate the saddle point of the function â„’â„’\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L. In each iteration k=1,2,â€¦,Kğ‘˜12â€¦ğ¾k=1,2,\dots,Kitalic_k = 1 , 2 , â€¦ , italic_K, the algorithm performs two updates: a primal update that corresponds to policy updates aiming to minimize â„’â„’\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L, and a dual update that computes action-value function estimates and aims to maximize â„’â„’\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L. Following a common terminology in reinforcement learning, we will sometimes refer to the primal updates as actor updates and the dual updates as critic updates.

In order to turn these insights into a practical algorithm, we define the following empirical estimate of the objective function â„’â„’\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L:

â„’^â¢(Ï€;Q)=1Ï„Eâ¢âˆ‘i=1Ï„E(Qâ¢(XEi,AEi)âˆ’Qâ¢(XEi,Ï€)).^â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„1subscriptğœEsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœEğ‘–1ğ‘„superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹Eğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ´Eğ‘–ğ‘„superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹Eğ‘–ğœ‹\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi;Q\right)=\frac{1}{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle% \textup{E}}}\sum^{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}_{i=1}\left(Q\left(X_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i},A_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i}\right)-% Q\left(X_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i},\pi\right)\right)\,.over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ; italic_Q ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Q ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_Q ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï€ ) ) .

For a fixed Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q and Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€, this is clearly an unbiased estimator of â„’â„’\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L. In line with the derivations above, we choose our critic and actor updates respectively as

QkâˆˆÂ argâ€‰maxQâˆˆğ’¬â„’^(Ï€k;Q),andÏ€k+1(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)=Ï€k(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)eÎ·â¢Qkâ¢(x,a)âˆ‘aâ€²âˆˆğ’œÏ€k(aâ€²\nonscript|\nonscriptx)eÎ·â¢Qkâ¢(x,aâ€²),Q_{k}\in\mathop{\mbox{ arg\,max}}_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}}\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(% \pi_{k};Q\right),\quad\text{and}\quad\;\pi_{k+1}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}% \middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)=\frac{\pi_{k}\left(a\nonscript% \mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)e^{\eta Q_{k}\left(x,a\right% )}}{\sum_{a^{\prime}\in\mathcal{A}}\pi_{k}\left(a^{\prime}\nonscript\mathpunct% {}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)e^{\eta Q_{k}\left(x,a^{\prime}\right)% }},italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ arg max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q ) , and italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_x ) = divide start_ARG italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_x ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_x ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ,

where Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0italic_Î· > 0 is a learning-rate (or stepsize) parameter that modulates the strength of the policy updates. After performing Kğ¾Kitalic_K updates, the algorithm chooses a random index Iğ¼Iitalic_I uniformly on the integers in [[1,K]]delimited-[]1ğ¾\left[\![1,K\right]\!][ [ 1 , italic_K ] ], and returns Ï€out=Ï€Isuperscriptğœ‹outsubscriptğœ‹ğ¼\pi^{\mathrm{out}}=\pi_{I}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We refer to this algorithm as Saddle-Point Offline Imitation Learning (SPOIL). This algorithm design is justified by the following simple error decomposition that lies at the heart of our main results.

Proposition 1.

Let Î”â¢(Ï€)=ğ”¼â¢[supQâˆˆğ’¬|â„’â¢(Ï€;Q)âˆ’â„’^â¢(Ï€;Q)|]Î”ğœ‹ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptsupremumğ‘„ğ’¬â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„^â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„\Delta\left(\pi\right)=\mathbb{E}\left[\sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}}\left|{\mathcal{L% }\left(\pi;Q\right)-\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi;Q\right)}\right|\right]roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ ) = blackboard_E [ roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ ; italic_Q ) - over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ; italic_Q ) | ]. The output of SPOIL satisfies

ğ”¼â¢[ÏÏ€Eâˆ’ÏÏ€out]â‰¤1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ”¼â¢[â„’â¢(Ï€k;Qk)]+2Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ”¼â¢[Î”â¢(Ï€k)].ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğœŒsubscriptğœ‹EsuperscriptğœŒsuperscriptğœ‹out1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜2ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]Î”subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\mathbb{E}\left[\rho^{{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}-\rho^{\pi^{\mathrm% {out}}}\right]\leq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\mathcal{L}\left(% \pi_{k};Q_{k}\right)\right]+\frac{2}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta% \left(\pi_{k}\right)\right]\,.blackboard_E [ italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] + divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] .
Proof.

The proof simply follows by noticing

ğ”¼â¢[ÏÏ€Eâˆ’ÏÏ€out]=1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ”¼â¢[â„’â¢(Ï€k;QÏ€k)]â‰¤1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ”¼â¢[â„’^â¢(Ï€k;QÏ€k)]+1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ”¼â¢[Î”â¢(Ï€k)]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğœŒsubscriptğœ‹EsuperscriptğœŒsuperscriptğœ‹out1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘„subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]^â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘„subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]Î”subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\rho^{{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}-\rho^% {\pi^{\mathrm{out}}}\right]=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\mathcal{% L}\left(\pi_{k};Q^{\pi_{k}}\right)\right]\leq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{% E}\left[\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k};Q^{\pi_{k}}\right)\right]+\frac{1}{% K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)\right]blackboard_E [ italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]
â‰¤1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ”¼â¢[â„’^â¢(Ï€k;Qk)]+1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ”¼â¢[Î”â¢(Ï€k)]â‰¤1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ”¼â¢[â„’â¢(Ï€k;Qk)]+2Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ”¼â¢[Î”â¢(Ï€k)],absent1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]^â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]Î”subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜2ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]Î”subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\displaystyle\qquad\leq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\widehat{% \mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k};Q_{k}\right)\right]+\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb% {E}\left[\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)\right]\leq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb% {E}\left[\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k};Q_{k}\right)\right]+\frac{2}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K% }\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)\right]\,,â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] + divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ,

where we have used the definitions of Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” and Qksubscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜Q_{k}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the first and second lines, respectively. âˆ

The first term in this decomposition corresponds to the regret of the policy player Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ against the comparator strategy Ï€Esubscriptğœ‹E{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and can be controlled with probability 1111 via standard tools of online learning (as found in the excellent books of Cesa-Bianchi and Lugosi 2006 and Orabona 2023). The second term measures the estimation error of the objective function â„’â„’\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L uniformly over the space of action-value functions ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q and along the policies played by the algorithm, and can be controlled via standard concentration arguments. Altogether, the proposition suggests that SPOIL will return a good policy if these estimation errors can be bounded reasonablyâ€”a fact we will formally show in the next section.

Before stating our performance guarantees for the concrete settings we consider in this paper, we pause to point out a peculiar connection between the algorithm described above and the inverse Q-learning (IQ-Learn) algorithm of Garg etÂ al. (2021). While motivated using completely different arguments, the saddle-point objective function optimized by IQ-Learn is nearly identical to our function â„’â„’\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L: after removing entropy-regularization and setting their reward regularizer Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ to zero, one can verify using the flow constraint (Eq.Â 1) that their function ğ’¥ğ’¥\mathcal{J}caligraphic_J is identical to our â„’â„’\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L. Ultimately, Garg etÂ al. (2021) draw different conclusions from this saddle-point formulation, and propose to solve it by computing Ï€Q=Â argâ€‰minÏ€ğ’¥â¢(Q)subscriptğœ‹ğ‘„subscriptÂ argâ€‰minğœ‹ğ’¥ğ‘„\pi_{Q}=\mathop{\mbox{ arg\,min}}_{\pi}\mathcal{J}\left(Q\right)italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = arg min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_J ( italic_Q ) and optimize the dual function gâ¢(Q)=minÏ€â¡â„’â¢(Ï€;Q)ğ‘”ğ‘„subscriptğœ‹â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„g\left(Q\right)=\min_{\pi}\mathcal{L}\left(\pi;Q\right)italic_g ( italic_Q ) = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ ; italic_Q ). This function, however, can be highly nonsmooth and difficult to optimize, which is why IQ-Learn needs to heavily rely on regularization both in Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q. In contrast, our algorithm can be seen as trying to optimize the primal function fâ¢(Ï€)=maxQâ¡â„’â¢(Ï€;Q)ğ‘“ğœ‹subscriptğ‘„â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„f\left(\pi\right)=\max_{Q}\mathcal{L}\left(\pi;Q\right)italic_f ( italic_Ï€ ) = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ ; italic_Q ) in terms of the policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€, which can be done in a stable way by incremental policy updates. Additionally, as PropositionÂ 1 clearly reveals, optimizing the primal objective allows us to directly reason about the performance of the output policy. In contrast, we do not see a clear way to do this for the dual objective optimized by IQ-Learn.

Furthermore, we also note that SPOIL shares similarities with the algorithm AdVIL proposed by Swamy etÂ al. (2021). Specifically, both SPOIL and AdVIL consider the same objective â„’â„’\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L but the two methods differ in their proposed algorithmic solutions and analytical approaches. Notably, Swamy etÂ al. (2021) employed simultaneous gradient descent-ascent updates that made little use of the specific problem structure, whereas we consider an asymmetric scheme where the policy player uses mirror descent and the Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q-player plays the best response. Therefore, our approach is more akin to minimizing the function Ï€â†¦maxQâˆˆğ’¬â¡â„’â¢(Ï€,Q)maps-toğœ‹subscriptğ‘„ğ’¬â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„\pi\mapsto\max_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}}\mathcal{L}\left(\pi,Q\right)italic_Ï€ â†¦ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ , italic_Q ) rather than using a primal-dual scheme. This is an important difference since PropositionÂ 1 makes evident that the best response update of the Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q player is crucial for our analysis.

In what follows, we instantiate SPOIL in two settings of particular interest, depending on the Q-function class being used. We first provide a set of results for linear function approximation (where the algorithm is very easy to implement and analyze) and for general function classes (where implementation and analysis are both less straightforward).

3.1 SPOIL for linear function approximation

We first provide a set of guarantees under the assumption that the function class is linear in some known features that realize the action-value functions of all policies Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ as linear combinations (see AssumptionÂ 1). In this setting, the actor and critic updates both simplify. For the actor, notice that the policy update can be rewritten as Ï€k(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆeÎ·â¢âˆ‘i=1kâˆ’1Qiâ¢(x,a)\pi_{k}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)% \propto e^{\eta\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}Q_{i}\left(x,a\right)}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_x ) âˆ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which only requires storing âˆ‘i=1kâˆ’1Qisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}Q_{i}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in memory. For linear function approximation, this means that it suffices to maintain a single dğ‘‘ditalic_d-dimensional vector Î¸Â¯k=âˆ‘i=1kÎ¸isubscriptÂ¯ğœƒğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘˜subscriptğœƒğ‘–\bar{\theta}_{k}=\sum_{i=1}^{k}\theta_{i}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in memory and update it incrementally after each critic update. As for the critic update itself, notice that the objective function â„’â„’\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L and its empirical counterpart â„’^^â„’\widehat{\mathcal{L}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG can be rewritten in terms of the gap between the feature-expectation vectors

gk=ğ”¼(X,A)âˆ¼Î¼Ï€Eâ¢[Ï†â¢(X,A)âˆ’Ï†â¢(X,Ï€k)],andg^k=1Ï„Eâ¢âˆ‘i=1Ï„E(Ï†â¢(XEi,AEi)âˆ’Ï†â¢(XEi,Ï€k)).formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘‹ğ´superscriptğœ‡subscriptğœ‹Edelimited-[]ğœ‘ğ‘‹ğ´ğœ‘ğ‘‹subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜andsubscript^ğ‘”ğ‘˜1subscriptğœEsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğœEğœ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹Eğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ´Eğ‘–ğœ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹Eğ‘–subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜g_{k}=\mathbb{E}_{\left(X,A\right)\sim\mu^{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}% }\left[\varphi\left(X,A\right)-\varphi\left(X,\pi_{k}\right)\right],\quad\mbox% {and}\quad\;\widehat{g}_{k}=\frac{1}{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\sum_% {i=1}^{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\left(\varphi\left(X_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i},A_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i}\right)-% \varphi\left(X_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i},\pi_{k}\right)\right)\,.italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X , italic_A ) âˆ¼ italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Ï† ( italic_X , italic_A ) - italic_Ï† ( italic_X , italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] , and over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï† ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_Ï† ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) .

When considering linear functions QÎ¸:(x,a)â†¦âŸ¨Ï†â¢(x,a),Î¸âŸ©:subscriptğ‘„ğœƒmaps-toğ‘¥ğ‘ğœ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘ğœƒQ_{\theta}\colon\left(x,a\right)\mapsto\left\langle\varphi\left(x,a\right),% \theta\right\rangleitalic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : ( italic_x , italic_a ) â†¦ âŸ¨ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_a ) , italic_Î¸ âŸ©, the objective can be written as

â„’â¢(Ï€k;QÎ¸)=âŸ¨Î¸,gkâŸ©,andâ„’^â¢(Ï€k;QÎ¸)=âŸ¨Î¸,g^kâŸ©,formulae-sequenceâ„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„ğœƒğœƒsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜and^â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„ğœƒğœƒsubscript^ğ‘”ğ‘˜\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k};Q_{\theta}\right)=\left\langle\theta,g_{k}\right% \rangle,\quad\mbox{and}\quad\;\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k};Q_{\theta}% \right)=\left\langle\theta,\widehat{g}_{k}\right\rangle\,,caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = âŸ¨ italic_Î¸ , italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© , and over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = âŸ¨ italic_Î¸ , over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© ,

and the critic update can be simply written as Î¸k=Â argâ€‰maxÎ¸âˆˆğ”…â¢(BÎ¸)âŸ¨Î¸,g^kâŸ©subscriptğœƒğ‘˜subscriptÂ argâ€‰maxğœƒğ”…subscriptğµğœƒğœƒsubscript^ğ‘”ğ‘˜\theta_{k}=\mathop{\mbox{ arg\,max}}_{\theta\in\mathfrak{B}\left(B_{\theta}% \right)}\left\langle\theta,\widehat{g}_{k}\right\rangleitalic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = arg max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ âˆˆ fraktur_B ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¨ italic_Î¸ , over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ©, which is trivial to compute. All in all, both actor and critic updates can be performed efficiently while only working in a dğ‘‘ditalic_d-dimensional Euclidean space. The following theorem provides our main result for SPOIL.

Theorem 1.

Let AssumptionÂ 1 hold. Run AlgorithmÂ 1 for K=2â¢logâ¡A(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Îµ2ğ¾2ğ´superscript1ğ›¾2superscriptğœ€2K=\frac{2\log A}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}italic_K = divide start_ARG 2 roman_log italic_A end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG iterations, with a learning rate Î·=(1âˆ’Î³)â¢2â¢logâ¡A/Kğœ‚1ğ›¾2ğ´ğ¾\eta=\left(1-\gamma\right)\sqrt{2\log A/K}italic_Î· = ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) square-root start_ARG 2 roman_log italic_A / italic_K end_ARG, and Ï„E=ğ’ªâ¢(d(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Îµ2â¢logâ¡(BÎ¸â¢BÏ†â¢A(1âˆ’Î³)â¢Îµ))subscriptğœEğ’ªğ‘‘superscript1ğ›¾2superscriptğœ€2subscriptğµğœƒsubscriptğµğœ‘ğ´1ğ›¾ğœ€\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{d}{\left(1-\gamma% \right)^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\log\left(\frac{B_{\theta}B_{\varphi}A}{\left(1-% \gamma\right)\varepsilon}\right)\right)italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_O ( divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) italic_Îµ end_ARG ) ) samples collected by any expert policy Ï€Esubscriptğœ‹E{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, the output satisfies ğ”¼â¢[ÏÏ€Eâˆ’ÏÏ€out]â‰¤5â¢Îµğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğœŒsubscriptğœ‹EsuperscriptğœŒsuperscriptğœ‹out5ğœ€\mathbb{E}\bigl{[}\rho^{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}-\rho^{\pi^{\mathrm% {out}}}\bigr{]}\leq 5\varepsilonblackboard_E [ italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ 5 italic_Îµ.

The proof is in AppendixÂ B.5. It is important to highlight that no assumptions are made concerning the expert policy. In particular, we do not require knowledge of a class Î EsuperscriptÎ E{\Pi^{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT realizing the expert policy and as a consequence the bound on Ï„EsubscriptğœE\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not scale at all with a complexity measure of Î EsuperscriptÎ E{\Pi^{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This is in stark contrast with the theoretical guarantees for behavioural cloning (e.g., Agarwal etÂ al., 2019, Chapter 15, and Foster etÂ al., 2024) which show bounds on the expert samples scaling with logâ¡|Î E|superscriptÎ E\log\left|{{\Pi^{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\right|roman_log | roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | (or the log covering number for continuous classes). It follows that no matter how complex the expert policy is, SPOIL suffers only the complexity of the environment (i.e., the feature dimensionality dğ‘‘ditalic_d).

3.2 SPOIL for general function approximation

For more complex QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable MDPs, we analyze the version of SPOIL given in AlgorithmÂ 2. Notice that the updates can no longer use the linear structure of the value functions, and thus the critic update cannot be computed in closed form. Nevertheless, the algorithm remains well-defined, and satisfies the following performance guarantee.

Theorem 2.

Let AssumptionÂ 2 hold. Run AlgorithmÂ 2 for K=2â¢logâ¡A(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Îµ2ğ¾2ğ´superscript1ğ›¾2superscriptğœ€2K=\frac{2\log A}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}italic_K = divide start_ARG 2 roman_log italic_A end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG iterations, with a learning rate Î·=(1âˆ’Î³)â¢2â¢logâ¡A/Kğœ‚1ğ›¾2ğ´ğ¾\eta=\left(1-\gamma\right)\sqrt{2\log A/K}italic_Î· = ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) square-root start_ARG 2 roman_log italic_A / italic_K end_ARG and Ï„E=ğ’ªâ¢(logâ¡A(1âˆ’Î³)4â¢Îµ4â¢logâ¡(ğ’©Ïµâ€²(ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)Îµâ¢(1âˆ’Î³)))\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}=\mathcal{O}\Bigl{(}\frac{\log A}{\left(1-% \gamma\right)^{4}\varepsilon^{4}}\log\Bigl{(}\frac{\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon^{% \prime}}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty}\right)}{\varepsilon% \left(1-\gamma\right)}\Bigr{)}\Bigr{)}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_O ( divide start_ARG roman_log italic_A end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) end_ARG ) ) samples collected by any expert Ï€Esubscriptğœ‹E{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Ïµâ€²=(128â¢K3/2â¢Aâ¢logâ¡A)âˆ’1superscriptitalic-Ïµâ€²superscript128superscriptğ¾32ğ´ğ´1\epsilon^{\prime}=\left(\sqrt{128}K^{3/2}A\log A\right)^{-1}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( square-root start_ARG 128 end_ARG italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A roman_log italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, the output satisfies ğ”¼â¢[ÏÏ€Eâˆ’ÏÏ€out]=ğ’ªâ¢(Îµ)ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğœŒsubscriptğœ‹EsuperscriptğœŒsuperscriptğœ‹outğ’ªğœ€\mathbb{E}\bigl{[}\rho^{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}-\rho^{\pi^{\mathrm% {out}}}\bigr{]}=\mathcal{O}\left(\varepsilon\right)blackboard_E [ italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = caligraphic_O ( italic_Îµ ).

There are two important remarks for the nonlinear extension. First, the maximization of â„’^â¢(Ï€k;Q)^â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘„\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k};Q\right)over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q ) with respect to Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q is no longer available in closed form and it might not even be a concave optimization problem depending on the choice of the function class ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q. Therefore, computational efficiency cannot be ensured. Nevertheless, the form of the objective function remains very simple in terms of Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q, and is arguably easier to optimize than other popular objective functions that are routinely optimized within deep RL with good empirical success (e.g., the objective functions appearing in (Mnih etÂ al., 2015)) and deep IL (Garg etÂ al., 2021). Secondly, the expert sample complexity bound degrades from ğ’ªâ¢(Îµâˆ’2)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€2\mathcal{O}\left(\varepsilon^{-2}\right)caligraphic_O ( italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) achieved in the linear case to ğ’ªâ¢(Îµâˆ’4)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€4\mathcal{O}\left(\varepsilon^{-4}\right)caligraphic_O ( italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) in the nonlinear case due to the higher complexity of the policies produced by the algorithm (which results in a larger covering number of the policy class as highlighted in the proof sketch included in the next section).

4 Analysis

In this section we outline the proof of our two main results. Both proofs are based on two key steps which are self evident from PropositionÂ 1. The first one consists of a regret analysis to show that âˆ‘k=1Kâ„’â¢(Ï€k;Qk)superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k};Q_{k}\right)âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is bounded sublinearly in Kğ¾Kitalic_K. At a high level, the proof makes use of a classic technique of decomposing the â€œglobalâ€ regret into the average of â€œlocalâ€ regrets in each MDP state, first proposed by Even-Dar etÂ al. ; Even-Dar etÂ al. (2009) and used in numerous other works (e.g., (Abbasi-Yadkori etÂ al., 2019; Geist etÂ al., 2019; Lan, 2023; Moulin and Neu, 2023)). In proving this result, a little care is needed in handling the potentially nonstationary nature of the expert policy. We circumvent the issue by using the performance difference lemma and controlling the regret at each state against the stationary comparator which induces the same state-action occupancy measure of the expert. Formally, we have the following bound, which we prove in AppendixÂ B.2.

Lemma 2.

For any kğ‘˜kitalic_k and any state-action pair (x,a)ğ‘¥ğ‘\left(x,a\right)( italic_x , italic_a ), consider the sequence of policies starting with Ï€1subscriptğœ‹1\pi_{1}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the uniform policy and updated as Ï€k+1(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆÏ€k(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)eÎ·â¢Qkâ¢(x,a)\pi_{k+1}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)% \propto\pi_{k}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x% \right)e^{\eta Q_{k}\left(x,a\right)}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_x ) âˆ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_x ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some function Qk:ğ’³Ã—ğ’œâ†’â„:subscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜â†’ğ’³ğ’œâ„Q_{k}\colon\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_A â†’ blackboard_R such that â€–Qkâ€–âˆâ‰¤11âˆ’Î³subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜11ğ›¾\left\|{Q_{k}}\right\|_{\infty}\leq\frac{1}{1-\gamma}âˆ¥ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Î³ end_ARG. Then, âˆ‘k=1Kâ„’â¢(Ï€k;Qk)â‰¤logâ¡AÎ·+Î·â¢K2â¢(1âˆ’Î³)2superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜ğ´ğœ‚ğœ‚ğ¾2superscript1ğ›¾2\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k};Q_{k}\right)\leq\frac{\log A}{\eta}+% \frac{\eta K}{2\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG roman_log italic_A end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_Î· italic_K end_ARG start_ARG 2 ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG.

This lemma applies to both the linear and nonlinear settings. The next and final step of the analysis is to establish concentration of the empirical objective and bound Î”â¢(Ï€k)Î”subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for each kğ‘˜kitalic_k. The main challenge in this step is the correlation between the iterates {Ï€k}k=1Ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ¾ğ‘˜1\left\{\pi_{k}\right\}^{K}_{k=1}{ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the expert dataset. This can be handled via a uniform bound over the policy class to which all the algorithm iterates belong to. Importantly, this class is much smaller than the class of all policies, and allows us to make massive sample-complexity savings as compared to methods that need to control estimation errors associated with arbitrary policies. We provide the technical details separately for the linear and nonlinear cases.

4.1 Linear function approximation

In order to bound the estimation errors Î”â¢(Ï€k)Î”subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), we apply a covering argument over the class of linear softmax policies. We have the following result.

Lemma 3.

Let {Ï€k}kâˆˆ[K]subscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾\left\{\pi_{k}\right\}_{k\in\left[K\right]}{ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the sequence of policies generated by AlgorithmÂ 1 and let Î”â¢(Ï€k)Î”subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) be defined as in PropositionÂ 1. Then, with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´, it holds that for all kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in\left[K\right]italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ]

Î”â¢(Ï€k)â‰¤1K+4â¢d(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Ï„Eâ¢logâ¡(2+32â¢K2â¢Î·â¢BÎ¸â¢BÏ†â¢A(1âˆ’Î³)â¢Î´),Î”subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜1ğ¾4ğ‘‘superscript1ğ›¾2subscriptğœE232superscriptğ¾2ğœ‚subscriptğµğœƒsubscriptğµğœ‘ğ´1ğ›¾ğ›¿\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)\leq\frac{1}{K}+4\sqrt{\frac{d}{\left(1-\gamma\right% )^{2}\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\log\left(\frac{2+32K^{2}\eta B_{% \theta}B_{\varphi}A}{\left(1-\gamma\right)\delta}\right)}\,,roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG + 4 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 + 32 italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) italic_Î´ end_ARG ) end_ARG ,

We defer the proof to AppendixÂ B.4. We can use the above result to sketch the proof of TheoremÂ 1.

Proof sketch of TheoremÂ 1.

Using LemmaÂ 2 with Î·=(1âˆ’Î³)â¢2â¢logâ¡AKğœ‚1ğ›¾2ğ´ğ¾\eta=\left(1-\gamma\right)\sqrt{\frac{2\log A}{K}}italic_Î· = ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log italic_A end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG end_ARG and dividing by Kğ¾Kitalic_K, we obtain that 1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kâ„’â¢(Ï€k;Qk)â‰¤2â¢logâ¡A(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢K1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜2ğ´superscript1ğ›¾2ğ¾\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k};Q_{k}\right)\leq\sqrt{\frac{% 2\log A}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}K}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log italic_A end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_ARG end_ARG. Therefore, setting K=2â¢logâ¡A(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Îµ2ğ¾2ğ´superscript1ğ›¾2superscriptğœ€2K=\frac{2\log A}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}italic_K = divide start_ARG 2 roman_log italic_A end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG guarantees 1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kâ„’â¢(Ï€k;Qk)â‰¤Îµ1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜ğœ€\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k};Q_{k}\right)\leq\varepsilondivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_Îµ. Then, using the high-probability bound in LemmaÂ 3 and the fact that Kâˆ’1â¢âˆ‘k=1KÎ”â¢(Ï€k)superscriptğ¾1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾Î”subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜K^{-1}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a random random variable bounded by (1âˆ’Î³)âˆ’1superscript1ğ›¾1\left(1-\gamma\right)^{-1}( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT almost surely, we obtain the following expectation bound which holds for all Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0italic_Î´ > 0

1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ”¼â¢[Î”â¢(Ï€k)]1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]Î”subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\displaystyle\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta\left(\pi_{k}% \right)\right]divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] â‰¤1K+Câ¢d(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Ï„Eâ¢logâ¡(BÎ¸â¢BÏ†â¢A(1âˆ’Î³)3â¢Îµ2â¢Î´)+Î´1âˆ’Î³,absent1ğ¾ğ¶ğ‘‘superscript1ğ›¾2subscriptğœEsubscriptğµğœƒsubscriptğµğœ‘ğ´superscript1ğ›¾3superscriptğœ€2ğ›¿ğ›¿1ğ›¾\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{K}+C\sqrt{\frac{d}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\log\left(\frac{B_{\theta}B_{\varphi}A}{\left(1-% \gamma\right)^{3}\varepsilon^{2}\delta}\right)}+\frac{\delta}{1-\gamma}\,,â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG + italic_C square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î´ end_ARG ) end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Î³ end_ARG ,

for some Câˆˆâ„ğ¶â„C\in\mathbb{R}italic_C âˆˆ blackboard_R. Noticing that the choice of parameters ensures 1Kâ‰¤Îµ21ğ¾ğœ€2\frac{1}{K}\leq\frac{\varepsilon}{2}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG and setting Î´=Îµâ¢(1âˆ’Î³)2ğ›¿ğœ€1ğ›¾2\delta=\frac{\varepsilon\left(1-\gamma\right)}{2}italic_Î´ = divide start_ARG italic_Îµ ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG and Ï„Eâ‰¥C2â¢d(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Îµ2â¢logâ¡(BÎ¸â¢BÏ†â¢A(1âˆ’Î³)3â¢Îµ2â¢Î´)subscriptğœEsuperscriptğ¶2ğ‘‘superscript1ğ›¾2superscriptğœ€2subscriptğµğœƒsubscriptğµğœ‘ğ´superscript1ğ›¾3superscriptğœ€2ğ›¿\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}\geq\frac{C^{2}d}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}% \varepsilon^{2}}\log\left(\frac{B_{\theta}B_{\varphi}A}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^% {3}\varepsilon^{2}\delta}\right)italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ divide start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î´ end_ARG ), this bound implies that 2Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ”¼â¢[Î”k]â‰¤4â¢Îµ2ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptÎ”ğ‘˜4ğœ€\frac{2}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta_{k}\right]\leq 4\varepsilondivide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] â‰¤ 4 italic_Îµ. Invoking PropositionÂ 1, we conclude that ğ”¼â¢[ÏÏ€Eâˆ’ÏÏ€out]â‰¤5â¢Ïµğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğœŒsubscriptğœ‹EsuperscriptğœŒsuperscriptğœ‹out5italic-Ïµ\mathbb{E}\bigl{[}\rho^{{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}-\rho^{\pi^{% \mathrm{out}}}\bigr{]}\leq 5\epsilonblackboard_E [ italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ 5 italic_Ïµ. The full proof is in AppendixÂ B.5. âˆ

4.2 General function approximation

The proof for the nonlinear setup follows the same conceptual steps but requires a more general concentration result for the objective function. Namely, the following lemma is the general counterpart of LemmaÂ 3. The feature dimension dğ‘‘ditalic_d appearing in the linear case is replaced by the complexity (as measured by the covering number) of the policy and value function classes containing the iterates.

Lemma 4.

Let Î ğ’¬subscriptÎ ğ’¬\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the policy class containing the iterates {Ï€k}k=1Ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ¾ğ‘˜1\left\{\pi_{k}\right\}^{K}_{k=1}{ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT produced by AlgorithmÂ 2, then with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´, for all kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in\left[K\right]italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ] it holds that

Î”â¢(Ï€k)=supQâˆˆğ’¬|â„’^â¢(Ï€k;Q)âˆ’â„’â¢(Ï€k;Q)|â‰¤12â¢K+2(K+1)log(2ğ’©1âˆ’Î³8â¢K2â¢Î·â¢A(ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)/Î´)(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Ï„E.\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)=\sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}}\left|{\widehat{\mathcal{L}}% \left(\pi_{k};Q\right)-\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k};Q\right)}\right|\leq\frac{1}{2% K}+\sqrt{\frac{2\left(K+1\right)\log\left({2\mathcal{N}_{\frac{1-\gamma}{8K^{2% }\eta A}}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty}\right)/\delta}% \right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\,.roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q ) - caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q ) | â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_K + 1 ) roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 - italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG 8 italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_Î´ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG .

The proof is in AppendixÂ B.6. Note that in the nonlinear case, the complexity of the policy class increases linearly with the number of iterations Kğ¾Kitalic_K (see LemmaÂ 7). On the contrary, in the linear case, the policies generated by AlgorithmÂ 1 are parameterized by dğ‘‘ditalic_d parameters and only the magnitude of these parameters increases with Kğ¾Kitalic_K. With this lemma, we present the proof sketch of TheoremÂ 2.

Proof sketch of TheoremÂ 2.

Applying the decomposition in PropositionÂ 1, the regret bound in LemmaÂ 2, the concentration in LemmaÂ 4, we obtain ğ”¼â¢[ÏÏ€Eâˆ’ÏÏ€out]=ğ’ª~â¢(1K+KÏ„E)ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğœŒsubscriptğœ‹EsuperscriptğœŒsuperscriptğœ‹out~ğ’ª1ğ¾ğ¾subscriptğœE\mathbb{E}\bigl{[}\rho^{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}-\rho^{\pi^{\mathrm% {out}}}\bigr{]}=\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\Bigl{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}+\sqrt{\frac{K}{% \tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\Bigr{)}blackboard_E [ italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = over~ start_ARG caligraphic_O end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_K end_ARG end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ). Setting K=ğ’ª~â¢(Îµâˆ’2)ğ¾~ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€2K=\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\varepsilon^{-2}\right)italic_K = over~ start_ARG caligraphic_O end_ARG ( italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), and Ï„E=ğ’ª~â¢(Îµâˆ’4)subscriptğœE~ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€4\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}=\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\varepsilon^{-4}\right)italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over~ start_ARG caligraphic_O end_ARG ( italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), we get ğ”¼â¢[ÏÏ€Eâˆ’ÏÏ€out]=Îµğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğœŒsubscriptğœ‹EsuperscriptğœŒsuperscriptğœ‹outğœ€\mathbb{E}\bigl{[}\rho^{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}-\rho^{\pi^{\mathrm% {out}}}\bigr{]}=\varepsilonblackboard_E [ italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = italic_Îµ. The full proof is in AppendixÂ B.7. âˆ

5 Numerical experiments

We conduct experiments to verify that we can efficiently imitate complex experts in linear QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT environments, and can achieve massive improvements over behavioral cloning with large policy classes.111Code is available at: https://github.com/antoine-moulin/spoil.

To investigate this, we consider a randomly generated large linear MDP (a special case of linear QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable MDP) with |ğ’³|=500ğ’³500\left|{\mathcal{X}}\right|=500| caligraphic_X | = 500 and A=1000ğ´1000A=1000italic_A = 1000 but with a small feature dimension d=7ğ‘‘7d=7italic_d = 7. We instantiate two experts. The first expert is trained to be the soft optimal policy in this environment. This policy is parametrized by only dğ‘‘ditalic_d parameters and can be realized by the following policy class Î linE={Ï€(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)=expâ¡(âŸ¨Ï†â¢(x,a),Î¸âŸ©)âˆ‘bâˆˆğ’œexpâ¡(âŸ¨Ï†â¢(x,b),Î¸âŸ©),Î¸âˆˆâ„d,âˆ¥Î¸âˆ¥â‰¤BÎ¸}{\Pi^{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}_{\mathrm{lin}}}=\left\{\pi\left(a% \nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)=\frac{\exp\left(% \left\langle\varphi\left(x,a\right),\theta\right\rangle\right)}{\sum_{b\in% \mathcal{A}}\exp\left(\left\langle\varphi\left(x,b\right),\theta\right\rangle% \right)},\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d},\left\|{\theta}\right\|\leq B_{\theta}\right\}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_Ï€ ( italic_a | italic_x ) = divide start_ARG roman_exp ( âŸ¨ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_a ) , italic_Î¸ âŸ© ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_exp ( âŸ¨ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_b ) , italic_Î¸ âŸ© ) end_ARG , italic_Î¸ âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , âˆ¥ italic_Î¸ âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. In addition, we consider the second expert, which belongs to the class of three-layer neural networks denoted by Î NNEsubscriptsuperscriptÎ ENN{\Pi^{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}_{\mathrm{NN}}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_NN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This expert was trained to minimize the KL divergence with respect to the linear expert. As evident from FigureÂ 1, our algorithm SPOIL performs well for both experts. This is in perfect agreement with the theory which provides a sample complexity bound that is independent of the expert policy class. On the other hand, behavioural cloning (BC) struggles with the complexity of the neural network expert policy class, and performs much worse. This is despite the fact that the dataset perfectly satisfies the realizability condition required by BC. This clearly demonstrates that complex behavior policies may indeed be problematic for BC to deal with, and we expect that such issues may also cause real performance drops in practical applications as well. Notice that in this experiment, SPOIL outperforms BC because the environment complexity is much lower than the policy class complexity. For fairness, we point out that the opposite situation is not unusual in RL and IL. In that case, it is reasonable to expect BC to be superior to SPOIL.

5.1 Continuous states experiments

We run the general function approximation version of our algorithm in continuous-states environments from the gym library (Towers etÂ al., 2024). In particular, we consider the environments CartPole-v1, Acrobot-v1 and LunarLander-v2 where the expert is trained via Soft DQN. We use the expert data provided in the code base of Garg etÂ al. (2021). The learner aims at imitating the expert performance given as input a variable number of expert trajectories. In order to make the task more challenging the trajectories are subsampled each 20202020 steps in CartPole-v1, Acrobot-v1 and each 5555 in LunarLander-v2.222This is common practice in IL experiments (see, e.g., Garg etÂ al., 2021). We compare the performance of the best policy found by each of these algorithms as a function of the number of expert trajectories given as input.

In practice the maximization Â argâ€‰maxQâˆˆğ’¬â„’^â¢(Ï€k,Q)subscriptÂ argâ€‰maxğ‘„ğ’¬^â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘„\mathop{\mbox{ arg\,max}}_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}}\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k},% Q\right)arg max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) is approximated by performing a gradient ascent step. On the other hand, the actor update is approximated via Soft DQN (Haarnoja etÂ al., 2017). In FigureÂ 2, we can see that SPOIL performs comparably to the state-of-the-art algorithm IQ-Learn (Garg etÂ al., 2021) and improves upon BC (Pomerleau, 1991; Foster etÂ al., 2024) and P2IL (Viano etÂ al., 2022).

6 Conclusions

In this work, we proposed analyses that leverages structural assumptions on the MDP without requiring trajectory access. This is made possible thanks to a novel regret decomposition that shifts the focus from updating a reward sequence based on expert data to updating a sequence of state-action value functions. To the best of our knowledge, these are the first rigorous theoretical guarantees for IL methods that learn state-action value functions from expert data, a technique popularized in practice by Garg etÂ al. (2021). Among the many potential ways to improve extend and improve our work, we highlight a handful of directions in AppendixÂ F.

All previous theory work has focused either on imitation learning with additional trajectory access to the environment, both in tabular MDPs (Shani etÂ al., 2021; Xu etÂ al., 2023) and with additional structural assumptions (Liu etÂ al., 2022; Viano etÂ al., 2022, 2024; Moulin etÂ al., 2025), or learning based on offline data only but under structural assumptions about the policy class used by the expert (Rajaraman etÂ al., 2021; Swamy etÂ al., 2022; Foster etÂ al., 2024; Rohatgi etÂ al., 2025). The first of these assumptions is clearly more restrictive than what we have considered in this work, and we have pointed out potential issues with the second set of methods when the policy class is exceedingly complex. This is not to say though that we consider our approach strictly superior to policy-based IL methods: as is often the case in RL, there is no single approach that dominates all others in all problems, and sometimes policy-based methods are more suitable for the job than value-based ones. Thus, even if our approach is not the ultimate answer to all questions in imitation learning, our results show that it is one potential alternative to consider in situations where other methods fail.

Acknowledgments and Disclosure of Funding

Luca Viano is funded through a PhD fellowship of the Swiss Data Science Center, a joint venture between EPFL and ETH Zurich. Gergely Neu and Antoine Moulin are funded through a European Research Council (ERC) project, under the European Unionâ€™s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (Grant agreement No. 950180).
