    4. B.4 Proof of LemmaÂ 3 (concentration linear case)
    5. B.5 Proof of TheoremÂ 1 (sample complexity guarantee for linear QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable MDPs)
    6. B.6 Proof of LemmaÂ 4 (concentration nonlinear case)
    7. B.7 Proof of TheoremÂ 2 (sample complexity guarantee for QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable MDPs)
  9. C Technical tools
  10. D On the guarantees of misspecified BC in linear QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable MDPs
  11. E Experimental details
  12. F Future directions

Appendix A Additional related works

Classical analyses by Ross and Bagnell [2010], Ross etÂ al. [2011] on behavioural cloning (BC) established an error propagation framework relating the suboptimality of the learned policy to the worst-case generalization error incurred in predicting the expert policy. They proved that this suboptimality gap is upper-bounded by the generalization error up to a multiplicative factor H2superscriptğ»2H^{2}italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (where Hğ»Hitalic_H is the horizon), a factor that is unavoidable when using the 0-1 loss for supervised learning. However, these results do not quantify the expert sample complexity, or the number of samples required to make the generalization error small.

A recent line of work has begun to investigate the expert sample complexity assuming knowledge of a policy class Î EsuperscriptÎ E{\Pi^{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that realizes (or nearly realizes) the expert policy. For instance, Rajaraman etÂ al. [2021] assume that the expert is deterministic and belongs to the class of deterministic linear policies Î det,linsubscriptÎ detlin\Pi_{\mathrm{det,lin}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_det , roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (defined in the caption of TableÂ 1). They prove a bound on the required number of expert samples of order ğ’ª~â¢((H2â¢d)/Îµ)~ğ’ªsuperscriptğ»2ğ‘‘ğœ€\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\left(H^{2}d\right)/{\varepsilon}\right)over~ start_ARG caligraphic_O end_ARG ( ( italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d ) / italic_Îµ ), where dğ‘‘ditalic_d is the feature dimension in the definition of Î det,linsubscriptÎ detlin\Pi_{\mathrm{det,lin}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_det , roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Their technique is a reduction to the problem of multiclass classification in supervised learning, but their result is not informative for settings with general stochastic expert policies.

Further contributions to understanding the sample complexity of IL under policy class assumptions were made by Foster etÂ al. [2024]. Specifically, assuming the expert is included within a known class, Ï€EâˆˆÎ Esubscriptğœ‹EsuperscriptÎ E{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\in{\Pi^{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, they showed that one can learn an Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ-optimal policy (as defined in EquationÂ (2)) after observing ğ’ªâ¢((H2â¢logâ¡|Î E|)/Îµ)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ»2superscriptÎ Eğœ€\mathcal{O}\left(\left(H^{2}\log\left|{{\Pi^{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}% \right|\right)/{\varepsilon}\right)caligraphic_O ( ( italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log | roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ) / italic_Îµ ) samples for a deterministic expert or ğ’ªâ¢((H2â¢logâ¡|Î E|)/Îµ2)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ»2superscriptÎ Esuperscriptğœ€2\mathcal{O}\left(\left(H^{2}\log\left|{{\Pi^{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}% \right|\right)/{\varepsilon^{2}}\right)caligraphic_O ( ( italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log | roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ) / italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) samples for a stochastic one (we report the dense reward case for brevity, though their bounds improve for sparse rewards). Addressing scenarios where the expert policy might only be almost well-specified, Rohatgi etÂ al. [2025] demonstrate that there exists a computationally efficient algorithm that outputs an Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ-optimal policy up to an additional approximation error of Hâ¢logâ¡(W)â¢minÏ€âˆˆÎ Eâ¡ğ’Ÿğ–§2â¢(â„™Ï€,â„™Ï€E)ğ»ğ‘Šsubscriptğœ‹superscriptÎ Esuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ–§2superscriptâ„™ğœ‹superscriptâ„™subscriptğœ‹EH\log\left(W\right)\min_{\pi\in{\Pi^{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\mathcal{D% }_{\mathsf{H}}^{2}\left(\mathbb{P}^{\pi},\mathbb{P}^{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle% \textup{E}}}\right)italic_H roman_log ( italic_W ) roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ âˆˆ roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). In this context, â„™Ï€superscriptâ„™ğœ‹\mathbb{P}^{\pi}blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the trajectory distribution induced by Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€, Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is a density ratio defined as

W=maxÏ€âˆˆÎ Eâ¡max(x,a)âˆˆğ’³Ã—ğ’œâ¡maxhâˆˆ[H]â¡Ï€E,h(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)Ï€h(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx).W=\max_{\pi\in{\Pi^{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\max_{\left(x,a\right)\in% \mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}}\max_{h\in\left[H\right]}\frac{{\pi_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E},h}}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|% \nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}{\pi_{h}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|% \nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}\,.italic_W = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ âˆˆ roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) âˆˆ caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h âˆˆ [ italic_H ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_x ) end_ARG .

It is worth noting that these guarantees become vacuous when the policy class Î EsuperscriptÎ E{\Pi^{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is such that at least one policy in Î EsuperscriptÎ E{\Pi^{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT fails to provide sufficient coverage for the expertâ€™s actions (leading to W=+âˆğ‘ŠW=+\inftyitalic_W = + âˆ as Ï€h(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)\pi_{h}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_x ) gets close to zero for relevant state-action pairs and timestep where Ï€E,h(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)>0{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E},h}}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|% \nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)>0italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_x ) > 0), or if the minimum Hellinger distance minÏ€âˆˆÎ Eâ¡ğ’Ÿğ–§2â¢(â„™Ï€,â„™Ï€E)subscriptğœ‹superscriptÎ Esuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ–§2superscriptâ„™ğœ‹superscriptâ„™subscriptğœ‹E\min_{\pi\in{\Pi^{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\mathcal{D}_{\mathsf{H}}^{2}% \left(\mathbb{P}^{\pi},\mathbb{P}^{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\right)roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ âˆˆ roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is large. Alternatively, Foster etÂ al. [2024] proved a misspecification result where the additional error is minÏ€âˆˆÎ Eâ¡Ï‡2â¢(â„™Ï€,â„™Ï€E)subscriptğœ‹superscriptÎ Esuperscriptğœ’2superscriptâ„™ğœ‹superscriptâ„™subscriptğœ‹E\min_{\pi\in{\Pi^{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\chi^{2}\left(\mathbb{P}^{\pi% },\mathbb{P}^{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\right)roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ âˆˆ roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). This misspecification error is measured by the Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divergence, with a leading coefficient constant in Hğ»Hitalic_H and Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W. However, the Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divergence is an upper bound on the Hellinger distance that is often way too loose to be practical. In a similar vein, Espinosa-Dice etÂ al. [2025] proved a benefit in terms of error propagation for a local search algorithm over behavioural cloning in misspecified settings, under the assumption that the learned policy is allowed to reset to states visited in the expert dataset.

Our work aligns with the recent renewed interest in proving refined expert sample complexity guarantees for offline imitation learning but distinguishes itself by swapping out the expert realizability assumption with a structural assumption on the environment. Early explorations for similar settings can be found in classical works by Abbeel and Ng [2004] and Syed and Schapire [2007]. These studies proposed offline learning algorithms for MDPs with reward functions linear in a collection of features known to the learner, under the assumption that transition dynamics of the environment is also known. Versions of their approaches that do not assume such knowledge typically incur a worse sample complexity and often apply only in the tabular setting. Our work generalizes these classical approaches by removing the need for known transitions and for rewards to be linear in the features, as well as going beyond tabular MDPs. Notably, the linear QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizability assumption can hold even if the reward function and the transition dynamics are nonlinear. We summarize our comparison with these and other related works in TableÂ 1.

Our work focuses on learning a Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q-value from expert data and, in this regard, is closely related to the practical work of Garg etÂ al. [2021]. The novel regret decomposition employed in our analysis of SPOIL demonstrates, we believe for the first time, that provable guarantees are achievable by directly learning an action-value function from expert data. This contrasts with the majority of theoretical and practical imitation learning approaches, which typically first use the expert data to learn a reward function and subsequently use this learned reward function to infer an action-value function.

As we mentioned, SPOIL is very related to AdVIL. However, a key difference lies in the analysis: Swamy etÂ al. [2021] conduct an error propagation analysis for AdVIL. From this, they conclude that AdVIL is equivalent to BC in the sense that if the loss for either method is at most Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ in every state, then the suboptimality of the extracted policy in an episodic setting with horizon Hğ»Hitalic_H is of order H2â¢Îµsuperscriptğ»2ğœ€H^{2}\varepsilonitalic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îµ for both. However, this type of result does not investigate the assumptions or the number of samples needed to ensure these losses are indeed less than Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ. Our work addresses this open question, establishing a clear distinction between the sample complexities of SPOIL and BC. Specifically, SPOIL and BC (and their respective analyses) rely on largely orthogonal sets of assumptions, making the two approaches complementary to each other: we expect SPOIL to be more suitable for imitation tasks with complex experts but simpler environments, while BC may be the preferred choice when this situation is reversed. Our sample complexity analysis for SPOIL critically relies on the Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q-player using a best response strategy, and it is unlikely that equivalent results could be achieved using a standard gradient ascent step for the Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q-player instead.

Very recently, Simchowitz etÂ al. [2025] analyzed the error propagation properties of offline imitation learning algorithms in continuous action MDPs, showing that an exponential dependence on the horizon of the problem is unavoidable if no structure is imposed on the environment. On the other hand, the same authors point out that if the state-action value functions were Lipschitz in the action space, then efficient learning would be possible. Conceptually, we believe that the SPOIL algorithm could also be applied in the continuous action case. Such an extension would suggest that another scenario enabling effective imitation learning in continuous action spaces arises when the learner has access to a suitably expressive class of state-action value functions.

Following a similar line of research that studies imitation learning from a control-theoretic perspective, Block etÂ al. [2023] studied guarantees for generative behavioural cloning, assuming access to a stabilizing policy dubbed a synthesis oracle. These policies can be computed exactly if the dynamics are known, an assumption which is not imposed in our work. However, when provided with such an oracle, Block etÂ al. [2023] derive bounds on a stricter metric for imitation. Specifically, they bound the probability that expert and learner trajectories diverge at some time step, as opposed to the difference in cumulative return that we analyze in our work.

Appendix B Omitted proofs

In this appendix, we provide the omitted proofs of the main results.

B.1 Proof of LemmaÂ 1 (performance difference lemma)

We start presenting the performance difference lemma proven in a more general form which allows one policy to be nonstationary.

See 1

Proof.

Consider the Bellman equations for the stationary policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€. For any state-action pair (x,a)ğ‘¥ğ‘\left(x,a\right)( italic_x , italic_a ), we have

B.2 Proof of LemmaÂ 2 (regret of the policy player)

Next, we apply LemmaÂ 10 to the special case of the exponential weights update, where the divergence is chosen to be the KL divergence, and use it to derive a bound on the regret of the policy player.

See 2

Proof.

Let us recall that

â„’â¢(Ï€k,Qk)=ğ”¼(X,A)âˆ¼Î¼Ï€Eâ¢[Qkâ¢(X,A)âˆ’Qkâ¢(X,Ï€k)],â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘‹ğ´superscriptğœ‡subscriptğœ‹Edelimited-[]subscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜ğ‘‹ğ´subscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜ğ‘‹subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k},Q_{k}\right)=\mathbb{E}_{\left(X,A\right)\sim\mu^{{% \pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}}\left[Q_{k}\left(X,A\right)-Q_{k}\left(X,% \pi_{k}\right)\right]\,,caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X , italic_A ) âˆ¼ italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X , italic_A ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X , italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ,

where Ï€Esubscriptğœ‹E{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a potentially nonstationary policy. To continue, let us consider the stationary policy Ï€Â¯E:ğ’³â†’Î”â¢(ğ’œ):subscriptÂ¯ğœ‹Eâ†’ğ’³Î”ğ’œ{\bar{\pi}_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\colon\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\Delta% \left(\mathcal{A}\right)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ï€ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : caligraphic_X â†’ roman_Î” ( caligraphic_A ) that induces the same state-action occupancy measure of the expert, i.e., such that Î¼Ï€Â¯E=Î¼Ï€Esuperscriptğœ‡subscriptÂ¯ğœ‹Esuperscriptğœ‡subscriptğœ‹E\mu^{\bar{\pi}_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}=\mu^{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle% \textup{E}}}italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ï€ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This equality can be guaranteed by choosing, for any (x,a)âˆˆğ’³Ã—ğ’œğ‘¥ğ‘ğ’³ğ’œ\left(x,a\right)\in\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}( italic_x , italic_a ) âˆˆ caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_A, Ï€Â¯E(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)=Î¼Ï€Eâ¢(x,a)Î½Ï€Eâ¢(x){\bar{\pi}_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle% |\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)=\frac{\mu^{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}% \left(x,a\right)}{\nu^{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\left(x\right)}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ï€ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_x ) = divide start_ARG italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) end_ARG if Î½Ï€Eâ¢(x)â‰ 0superscriptğœˆsubscriptğœ‹Eğ‘¥0\nu^{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\left(x\right)\neq 0italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) â‰  0 and Ï€0â¢(a)subscriptğœ‹0ğ‘\pi_{0}\left(a\right)italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a ) otherwise, where Ï€0âˆˆÎ”â¢(ğ’œ)subscriptğœ‹0Î”ğ’œ\pi_{0}\in\Delta\left(\mathcal{A}\right)italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î” ( caligraphic_A ) is an arbitrary distribution. Then, we continue as follows

It remains to prove the following bound.

âˆ‘k=1Kâˆ‘aâˆˆğ’œQk(x,a)(Ï€Â¯E(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ’Ï€k(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx))â‰¤logâ¡AÎ·+Î·â¢K2â¢(1âˆ’Î³)2.\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sum_{a\in\mathcal{A}}Q_{k}\left(x,a\right)\left({% \bar{\pi}_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|% \nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)-\pi_{k}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|% \nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)\right)\leq\frac{\log A}{\eta}+\frac{\eta K}{2% \left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}}\,.âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ï€ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_x ) - italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_x ) ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG roman_log italic_A end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_Î· italic_K end_ARG start_ARG 2 ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG .

The result is proven as a particular case of LemmaÂ 10. Specifically, we have that when Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V is the Ağ´Aitalic_A-dimensional simplex and the Bregman divergence is the KL divergence, it holds that

and the conclusion follows from Î½Ï€Â¯EsuperscriptğœˆsubscriptÂ¯ğœ‹E\nu^{\bar{\pi}_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ï€ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT being a probability distribution. âˆ

B.3 General concentration argument

To prove the main results of this paper, we prove a general concentration inequality that we will use for the iterates produced by both AlgorithmÂ 1 and AlgorithmÂ 2. Specifically, when analyzing AlgorithmÂ 1, we consider the policy class Î linsubscriptÎ lin\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT defined as follows

Î lin={Ï€âˆˆÎ”(ğ’œ)ğ’³:âˆƒ(Î¸k)kâˆˆ[K]âŠ‚ğ”…(BÎ¸),Ï€(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)=expâ¡(Î·â¢âˆ‘k=1KâŸ¨Ï†â¢(x,a),Î¸kâŸ©)âˆ‘bâˆˆğ’œexpâ¡(Î·â¢âˆ‘k=1KâŸ¨Ï†â¢(x,b),Î¸kâŸ©)},\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}}=\left\{\pi\in\Delta\left(\mathcal{A}\right)^{\mathcal{X}}:% \exists\left(\theta_{k}\right)_{k\in[K]}\subset\mathfrak{B}\left(B_{\theta}% \right),\pi\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)% =\frac{\exp\left(\eta\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\langle\varphi\left(x,a\right),\theta_% {k}\right\rangle\right)}{\sum_{b\in\mathcal{A}}\exp\left(\eta\sum_{k=1}^{K}% \left\langle{\varphi\left(x,b\right)},{\theta_{k}}\right\rangle\right)}\right% \}\,,roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_Ï€ âˆˆ roman_Î” ( caligraphic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : âˆƒ ( italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‚ fraktur_B ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_Ï€ ( italic_a | italic_x ) = divide start_ARG roman_exp ( italic_Î· âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ¨ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_a ) , italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_exp ( italic_Î· âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ¨ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_b ) , italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© ) end_ARG } , (3)

while in the nonlinear case (AlgorithmÂ 2), we will consider the policy class

Î ğ’¬={Ï€âˆˆÎ”(ğ’œ)ğ’³:âˆƒ(Qk)kâˆˆ[K]âŠ‚ğ’¬,Ï€(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)=expâ¡(Î·â¢âˆ‘k=1KQkâ¢(x,a))âˆ‘bâˆˆğ’œexpâ¡(Î·â¢âˆ‘k=1KQkâ¢(x,b))}.\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}=\left\{\pi\in\Delta\left(\mathcal{A}\right)^{\mathcal{X}}:% \exists\left(Q_{k}\right)_{k\in[K]}\subset\mathcal{Q},\pi\left(a\nonscript% \mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)=\frac{\exp\left(\eta\sum_{k% =1}^{K}Q_{k}\left(x,a\right)\right)}{\sum_{b\in\mathcal{A}}\exp\left(\eta\sum_% {k=1}^{K}Q_{k}\left(x,b\right)\right)}\right\}\,.roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_Ï€ âˆˆ roman_Î” ( caligraphic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : âˆƒ ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‚ caligraphic_Q , italic_Ï€ ( italic_a | italic_x ) = divide start_ARG roman_exp ( italic_Î· âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_exp ( italic_Î· âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_b ) ) end_ARG } . (4)

The result is the following.

Lemma 5.

Let us consider a value function class ğ’¬âŠ‚â„ğ’³Ã—ğ’œğ’¬superscriptâ„ğ’³ğ’œ\mathcal{Q}\subset\mathbb{R}^{\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_Q âŠ‚ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the sequences of estimated objective functions {â„’^â¢(Ï€k,Q)}k=1Ksubscriptsuperscript^â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘„ğ¾ğ‘˜1\left\{{\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k},Q\right)}\right\}^{K}_{k=1}{ over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for a policy sequence {Ï€k}k=1Ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ¾ğ‘˜1\left\{{\pi_{k}}\right\}^{K}_{k=1}{ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT belonging to a policy class Î Î \Piroman_Î . For any kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in\left[K\right]italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ], recall that for any policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ and function Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q, the objective function is defined as

â„’â¢(Ï€;Q)=ğ”¼(X,A)âˆ¼Î¼Ï€Eâ¢[Qâ¢(X,A)âˆ’Qâ¢(X,Ï€)].â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘‹ğ´superscriptğœ‡subscriptğœ‹Edelimited-[]ğ‘„ğ‘‹ğ´ğ‘„ğ‘‹ğœ‹\mathcal{L}\left(\pi;Q\right)=\mathbb{E}_{\left(X,A\right)\sim\mu^{\pi_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\left[Q\left(X,A\right)-Q\left(X,\pi\right)% \right]\,.caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ ; italic_Q ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X , italic_A ) âˆ¼ italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Q ( italic_X , italic_A ) - italic_Q ( italic_X , italic_Ï€ ) ] .

Then, with probability larger than 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´, it holds that for all kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in\left[K\right]italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ] simultaneously that

Î”â¢(Ï€k)=supQâˆˆğ’¬|â„’^â¢(Ï€k,Q)âˆ’â„’â¢(Ï€k,Q)|â‰¤infÏµ:Ïµ>0{4â¢Ïµ1âˆ’Î³+2log(2ğ’©Ïµ(ğ’¬Ã—Î ,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ,1)/Î´)(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Ï„E},\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)=\sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}}\left|{\widehat{\mathcal{L}}% \left(\pi_{k},Q\right)-\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k},Q\right)}\right|\leq\inf_{% \epsilon:\epsilon>0}\left\{\frac{4\epsilon}{1-\gamma}+\sqrt{\frac{2\log\left(2% \mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi,\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{% \infty,1}\right)/\delta\right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\right\}\,,roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) - caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) | â‰¤ roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ : italic_Ïµ > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { divide start_ARG 4 italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Î³ end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î  , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_Î´ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG } ,

where, for any (Q,Ï€)âˆˆğ’¬Ã—Î ğ‘„ğœ‹ğ’¬Î \left(Q,\pi\right)\in\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi( italic_Q , italic_Ï€ ) âˆˆ caligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î , we defined the norm âˆ¥(Q,Ï€)âˆ¥âˆ,1=âˆ¥Qâˆ¥âˆ+maxxâˆˆğ’³âˆ¥Ï€(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ¥1\left\|{\left(Q,\pi\right)}\right\|_{\infty,1}=\left\|{Q}\right\|_{\infty}+% \max_{x\in\mathcal{X}}\left\|{\pi\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|% \nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}\right\|_{1}âˆ¥ ( italic_Q , italic_Ï€ ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ¥ italic_Q âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Ï€ ( â‹… | italic_x ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof.

Let us recall that for any Qâˆˆğ’¬ğ‘„ğ’¬Q\in\mathcal{Q}italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_Q and any kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in\left[K\right]italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ], we have

â„’^(Ï€k,Q)=1Ï„Eâˆ‘i=1Ï„E(Q(XEi,AEi)âˆ’âˆ‘aâˆˆğ’œÏ€k(a\nonscript|\nonscriptXEi)Q(XEi,a)),\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k},Q\right)=\frac{1}{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle% \textup{E}}}\sum^{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}_{i=1}\left(Q\left(X_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i},A_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i}\right)-% \sum_{a\in\mathcal{A}}\pi_{k}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript% \mathpunct{}X_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i}\right)Q\left(X_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i},a\right)\right)\,,over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Q ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_Q ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a ) ) ,

and notice that â„’^â¢(Ï€k,Q)^â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘„\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k},Q\right)over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) is not an unbiased estimator of â„’â¢(Ï€k,Q)â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘„\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k},Q\right)caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) since the policy Ï€ksubscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\pi_{k}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT depends on the expert data. Therefore, we aim at establishing a uniform concentration bound over the policy class Î Î \Piroman_Î . To this end, let us consider a fixed pair (Q,Ï€)âˆˆğ’Ïµ(ğ’¬Ã—Î ,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ,1)\left(Q,\pi\right)\in\mathcal{C}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi,\left\|{% \cdot}\right\|_{\infty,1}\right)( italic_Q , italic_Ï€ ) âˆˆ caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î  , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and notice that â„’^â¢(Ï€,Q)^â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi,Q\right)over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ , italic_Q ) is a sum of random variables of the form

where iâˆˆ[Ï„E]ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğœEi\in\left[\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}\right]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]. Thus, for any iâˆˆ[Ï„E]ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğœEi\in\left[\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}\right]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], ğ”¼â¢[Wi]=â„’â¢(Ï€,Q)ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘Šğ‘–â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„\mathbb{E}\left[W_{i}\right]=\mathcal{L}\left(\pi,Q\right)blackboard_E [ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ , italic_Q ). Moreover, notice that for all iâˆˆ[Ï„E]ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğœEi\in\left[\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}\right]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], âˆ’1Ï„Eâ¢(1âˆ’Î³)â‰¤Wiâ‰¤1Ï„Eâ¢(1âˆ’Î³)1subscriptğœE1ğ›¾subscriptğ‘Šğ‘–1subscriptğœE1ğ›¾-\frac{1}{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}\left(1-\gamma\right)}\leq W_{i}% \leq\frac{1}{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}\left(1-\gamma\right)}- divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) end_ARG â‰¤ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) end_ARG. Therefore, by an application of Hoeffdingâ€™s inequality (see LemmaÂ 9), we have that for all t>0ğ‘¡0t>0italic_t > 0,

â„™â¢[|â„’^â¢(Ï€,Q)âˆ’â„’â¢(Ï€,Q)|â‰¥t]â‰¤2â¢expâ¡(âˆ’2â¢t2â¢Ï„Eâ¢(1âˆ’Î³)24).â„™delimited-[]^â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„ğ‘¡22superscriptğ‘¡2subscriptğœEsuperscript1ğ›¾24\mathbb{P}\left[\left|{\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi,Q\right)-\mathcal{L}% \left(\pi,Q\right)}\right|\geq t\right]\leq 2\exp\left(-\frac{2t^{2}\tau_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}}{4}\right)\,.blackboard_P [ | over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ , italic_Q ) - caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ , italic_Q ) | â‰¥ italic_t ] â‰¤ 2 roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG 2 italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ) .

That is, choosing t=2â¢logâ¡(2/Î´)(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Ï„Eğ‘¡22ğ›¿superscript1ğ›¾2subscriptğœEt=\frac{2\log\left(2/\delta\right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}italic_t = divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( 2 / italic_Î´ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG guarantees that with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´,

|â„’^â¢(Ï€,Q)âˆ’â„’â¢(Ï€,Q)|â‰¤2â¢logâ¡(2/Î´)(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Ï„E.^â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„â„’ğœ‹ğ‘„22ğ›¿superscript1ğ›¾2subscriptğœE\left|{\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi,Q\right)-\mathcal{L}\left(\pi,Q\right)}% \right|\leq\sqrt{\frac{2\log\left(2/\delta\right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}% \tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\,.| over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ , italic_Q ) - caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ , italic_Q ) | â‰¤ square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( 2 / italic_Î´ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG .

Applying a union bound, we further have that with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´, for all (Q,Ï€)âˆˆğ’Ïµ(ğ’¬Ã—Î ,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ,1)\left(Q,\pi\right)\in\mathcal{C}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi,\left\|{% \cdot}\right\|_{\infty,1}\right)( italic_Q , italic_Ï€ ) âˆˆ caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î  , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) it holds that

|â„’^â¢(Ï€,Q)âˆ’â„’â¢(Ï€,Q)|â‰¤2log(2ğ’©Ïµ(ğ’¬Ã—Î ,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ,1)/Î´)(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Ï„E.\left|{\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi,Q\right)-\mathcal{L}\left(\pi,Q\right)}% \right|\leq\sqrt{\frac{2\log\left(2\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}% \times\Pi,\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty,1}\right)/\delta\right)}{\left(1-% \gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\,.| over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ , italic_Q ) - caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ , italic_Q ) | â‰¤ square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î  , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_Î´ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG .

Recall that ğ’Ïµ(ğ’¬Ã—Î ,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ,1)\mathcal{C}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi,\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{% \infty,1}\right)caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î  , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is assumed to be an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-covering set of the space ğ’¬Ã—Î ğ’¬Î \mathcal{Q}\times\Picaligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î  with respect to the norm (Q,Ï€)â†¦âˆ¥(Q,Ï€)âˆ¥âˆ,1=âˆ¥Qâˆ¥âˆ+maxxâˆˆğ’³âˆ¥Ï€(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ¥1\left(Q,\pi\right)\mapsto\left\|{\left(Q,\pi\right)}\right\|_{\infty,1}=\left% \|{Q}\right\|_{\infty}+\max_{x\in\mathcal{X}}\left\|{\pi\left(\cdot\nonscript% \mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}\right\|_{1}( italic_Q , italic_Ï€ ) â†¦ âˆ¥ ( italic_Q , italic_Ï€ ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ¥ italic_Q âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Ï€ ( â‹… | italic_x ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For any pair (Q,Ï€k)âˆˆğ’¬Ã—Î ğ‘„subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ’¬Î \left(Q,\pi_{k}\right)\in\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi( italic_Q , italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ caligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î , let (QÏµ,Ï€k,Ïµ)âˆˆğ’Ïµ(ğ’¬Ã—Î ,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ,1)\left(Q_{\epsilon},\pi_{k,\epsilon}\right)\in\mathcal{C}_{\epsilon}\left(% \mathcal{Q}\times\Pi,\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty,1}\right)( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î  , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) denote the element of the covering such that â€–(Q,Ï€k)âˆ’(QÏµ,Ï€k,Ïµ)â€–âˆ,1â‰¤Ïµsubscriptnormğ‘„subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„italic-Ïµsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµ\left\|{\left(Q,\pi_{k}\right)-\left(Q_{\epsilon},\pi_{k,\epsilon}\right)}% \right\|_{\infty,1}\leq\epsilonâˆ¥ ( italic_Q , italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ. Then, we have that

|â„’^â¢(Ï€k,Q)âˆ’â„’^â¢(Ï€k,Ïµ,QÏµ)|^â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘„^â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜italic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘„italic-Ïµ\displaystyle\left|{\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k},Q\right)-\widehat{% \mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k,\epsilon},Q_{\epsilon}\right)}\right|| over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) - over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | â‰¤|1Ï„Eâ¢âˆ‘i=1Ï„E(Qâ¢(XEi,AEi)âˆ’QÏµâ¢(XEi,AEi))|absent1subscriptğœEsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœEğ‘–1ğ‘„superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹Eğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ´Eğ‘–subscriptğ‘„italic-Ïµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‹Eğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ´Eğ‘–\displaystyle\leq\left|{\frac{1}{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\sum^{% \tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}_{i=1}\left(Q\left(X_{\scriptscriptstyle% \textup{E}}^{i},A_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i}\right)-Q_{\epsilon}\left(% X_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i},A_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i}% \right)\right)}\right|â‰¤ | divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Q ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) |
+|1Ï„Eâˆ‘i=1Ï„Eâˆ‘aâˆˆğ’œ(Ï€k,Ïµ(a\nonscript|\nonscriptXEi)QÏµ(XEi,a)âˆ’Ï€k(a\nonscript|\nonscriptXEi)Q(XEi,a))|\displaystyle\phantom{\leq}+\left|{\frac{1}{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}% }}\sum^{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}_{i=1}\sum_{a\in\mathcal{A}}\left(% \pi_{k,\epsilon}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}X_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i}\right)Q_{\epsilon}\left(X_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i},a\right)-\pi_{k}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{% }\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}X_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i}\right)Q% \left(X_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i},a\right)\right)}\right|+ | divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a ) - italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_Q ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a ) ) |
â‰¤âˆ¥Qâˆ’QÏµâˆ¥âˆ+|1Ï„Eâˆ‘i=1Ï„Eâˆ‘aâˆˆğ’œ(Ï€k,Ïµ(a\nonscript|\nonscriptXEi)âˆ’Ï€k(a\nonscript|\nonscriptXEi))QÏµ(XEi,a)|\displaystyle\leq\left\|{Q-Q_{\epsilon}}\right\|_{\infty}+\left|{\frac{1}{\tau% _{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\sum^{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}_{i=% 1}\sum_{a\in\mathcal{A}}\left(\pi_{k,\epsilon}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}% \middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}X_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i}\right)-\pi_% {k}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}X_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i}\right)\right)Q_{\epsilon}\left(X_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i},a\right)}\right|â‰¤ âˆ¥ italic_Q - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + | divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a ) |
+|1Ï„Eâˆ‘i=1Ï„Eâˆ‘aâˆˆğ’œÏ€k(a\nonscript|\nonscriptXEi)(Q(XEi,a)âˆ’QÏµ(XEi,a))|.\displaystyle\phantom{\leq}+\left|{\frac{1}{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}% }}\sum^{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}_{i=1}\sum_{a\in\mathcal{A}}\pi_{k% }\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}X_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i}\right)\left(Q\left(X_{\scriptscriptstyle% \textup{E}}^{i},a\right)-Q_{\epsilon}\left(X_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i% },a\right)\right)}\right|\,.+ | divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ( italic_Q ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a ) ) | .

|â„’â¢(Ï€k,Q)âˆ’â„’â¢(Ï€k,Ïµ,QÏµ)|â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘„â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜italic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘„italic-Ïµ\displaystyle\left|{\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k},Q\right)-\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k,% \epsilon},Q_{\epsilon}\right)}\right|| caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) - caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | â‰¤|ğ”¼(X,A)âˆ¼Î¼Ï€Eâ¢[Qâ¢(X,A)âˆ’QÏµâ¢(X,A)]|absentsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘‹ğ´superscriptğœ‡subscriptğœ‹Edelimited-[]ğ‘„ğ‘‹ğ´subscriptğ‘„italic-Ïµğ‘‹ğ´\displaystyle\leq\left|{\mathbb{E}_{\left(X,A\right)\sim\mu^{\pi_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\left[Q\left(X,A\right)-Q_{\epsilon}\left(X,A% \right)\right]}\right|â‰¤ | blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X , italic_A ) âˆ¼ italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Q ( italic_X , italic_A ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X , italic_A ) ] |

+|ğ”¼Xâˆ¼Î½Ï€Eâ¢[Qâ¢(X,Ï€k,Ïµ)âˆ’QÏµâ¢(X,Ï€k,Ïµ)]|subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘‹superscriptğœˆsubscriptğœ‹Edelimited-[]ğ‘„ğ‘‹subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜italic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘„italic-Ïµğ‘‹subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜italic-Ïµ\displaystyle\phantom{\leq}+\left|{\mathbb{E}_{X\sim\nu^{\pi_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\left[Q\left(X,\pi_{k,\epsilon}\right)-Q_{% \epsilon}\left(X,\pi_{k,\epsilon}\right)\right]}\right|+ | blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X âˆ¼ italic_Î½ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Q ( italic_X , italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X , italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] |
â‰¤â€–Qâˆ’QÏµâ€–âˆ+maxxâˆˆğ’³âˆ¥Ï€k,Ïµ(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ’Ï€k(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ¥11âˆ’Î³+â€–Qâˆ’QÏµâ€–âˆ\displaystyle\leq\left\|{Q-Q_{\epsilon}}\right\|_{\infty}+\frac{\max_{x\in% \mathcal{X}}\left\|{\pi_{k,\epsilon}\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|% \nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)-\pi_{k}\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle% |\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}\right\|_{1}}{1-\gamma}+\left\|{Q-Q_{\epsilon}% }\right\|_{\infty}â‰¤ âˆ¥ italic_Q - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( â‹… | italic_x ) - italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( â‹… | italic_x ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Î³ end_ARG + âˆ¥ italic_Q - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
â‰¤2â¢Ïµ1âˆ’Î³.absent2italic-Ïµ1ğ›¾\displaystyle\leq\frac{2\epsilon}{1-\gamma}\,.â‰¤ divide start_ARG 2 italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Î³ end_ARG .

Therefore, with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´, it holds that for any kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in\left[K\right]italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ] and any Qâˆˆğ’¬ğ‘„ğ’¬Q\in\mathcal{Q}italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_Q,

|â„’^â¢(Ï€k,Q)âˆ’â„’â¢(Ï€k,Q)|^â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘„â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘„\displaystyle\left|{\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k},Q\right)-\mathcal{L}% \left(\pi_{k},Q\right)}\right|| over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) - caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) | â‰¤|â„’^â¢(Ï€k,Q)âˆ’â„’^â¢(Ï€k,Ïµ,QÏµ)|+|â„’^â¢(Ï€k,Ïµ,QÏµ)âˆ’â„’â¢(Ï€k,Ïµ,QÏµ)|absent^â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘„^â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜italic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘„italic-Ïµ^â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜italic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘„italic-Ïµâ„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜italic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘„italic-Ïµ\displaystyle\leq\left|{\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k},Q\right)-\widehat{% \mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k,\epsilon},Q_{\epsilon}\right)}\right|+\left|{\widehat% {\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k,\epsilon},Q_{\epsilon}\right)-\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{% k,\epsilon},Q_{\epsilon}\right)}\right|â‰¤ | over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) - over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | + | over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) |
+|â„’â¢(Ï€k,Q)âˆ’â„’â¢(Ï€k,Ïµ,QÏµ)|â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘„â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜italic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘„italic-Ïµ\displaystyle\phantom{\leq}+\left|{\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k},Q\right)-\mathcal{% L}\left(\pi_{k,\epsilon},Q_{\epsilon}\right)}\right|+ | caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) - caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) |
â‰¤4â¢Ïµ1âˆ’Î³+2log(2ğ’©Ïµ(ğ’¬Ã—Î ,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ,1)/Î´)(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Ï„E.\displaystyle\leq\frac{4\epsilon}{1-\gamma}+\sqrt{\frac{2\log\left(2\mathcal{N% }_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi,\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty,1}\right% )/\delta\right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}% }\,.â‰¤ divide start_ARG 4 italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Î³ end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î  , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_Î´ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG .

Moreover, since the above bound holds for all Qâˆˆğ’¬ğ‘„ğ’¬Q\in\mathcal{Q}italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_Q, it holds for the supremum over this class. With probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´, we have for any kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in\left[K\right]italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ] that

supQâˆˆğ’¬|â„’^â¢(Ï€k,Q)âˆ’â„’â¢(Ï€k,Q)|â‰¤4â¢Ïµ1âˆ’Î³+2log(2ğ’©Ïµ(ğ’¬Ã—Î ,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ,1)/Î´)(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Ï„E.\displaystyle\sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}}\left|{\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k},Q% \right)-\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k},Q\right)}\right|\leq\frac{4\epsilon}{1-\gamma% }+\sqrt{\frac{2\log\left(2\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi,% \left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty,1}\right)/\delta\right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^% {2}\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\,.roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) - caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) | â‰¤ divide start_ARG 4 italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Î³ end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î  , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_Î´ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG .

The proof is concluded by noting that the above proof holds for any covering size Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0. âˆ

B.4 Proof of LemmaÂ 3 (concentration linear case)

We now instantiate LemmaÂ 5 in the linear QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable setting. For this purpose, we compute a bound on the covering number of the class Î linsubscriptÎ lin\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, defined in EquationÂ (3).

Lemma 6 (Covering number of Î linsubscriptÎ lin\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT).

It holds that the covering number of the policy class Î linsubscriptÎ lin\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be bounded as

ğ’©Ïµ(Î lin,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥1)â‰¤(1+2â¢Kâ¢Î·â¢BÎ¸â¢BÏ†â¢AÏµ)d,\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}% \right)\leq\left(1+\frac{2K\eta B_{\theta}B_{\varphi}A}{\epsilon}\right)^{d}\,,caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ ( 1 + divide start_ARG 2 italic_K italic_Î· italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where, with a slight abuse of notation, âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥1\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the norm defined for any Ï€âˆˆÎ linğœ‹subscriptÎ lin\pi\in\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}}italic_Ï€ âˆˆ roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as âˆ¥Ï€âˆ¥1=supxâˆˆğ’³âˆ¥Ï€(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ¥1\left\|{\pi}\right\|_{1}=\sup_{x\in\mathcal{X}}\left\|{\pi\left(\cdot% \nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}\right\|_{1}âˆ¥ italic_Ï€ âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Ï€ ( â‹… | italic_x ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Moreover, let

ğ’¬lin={Q:ğ’³Ã—ğ’œâ†’â„:âˆƒÎ¸âˆˆğ”…â¢(BÎ¸),âˆ€(x,a)âˆˆğ’³Ã—ğ’œ,Qâ¢(x,a)=âŸ¨Î¸,Ï†â¢(x,a)âŸ©}subscriptğ’¬linconditional-setğ‘„:â†’ğ’³ğ’œâ„formulae-sequenceğœƒğ”…subscriptğµğœƒformulae-sequencefor-allğ‘¥ğ‘ğ’³ğ’œğ‘„ğ‘¥ğ‘ğœƒğœ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘\mathcal{Q}_{\mathrm{lin}}=\left\{Q\colon\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}% \rightarrow\mathbb{R}:\exists\theta\in\mathfrak{B}\left(B_{\theta}\right),% \forall\left(x,a\right)\in\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A},\;Q\left(x,a\right)=% \left\langle\theta,\varphi\left(x,a\right)\right\rangle\right\}caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_Q : caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_A â†’ blackboard_R : âˆƒ italic_Î¸ âˆˆ fraktur_B ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , âˆ€ ( italic_x , italic_a ) âˆˆ caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_A , italic_Q ( italic_x , italic_a ) = âŸ¨ italic_Î¸ , italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_a ) âŸ© }

be the class of linear action-value functions. Then, it holds that

ğ’©Ïµ(ğ’¬linÃ—Î lin,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ,1)â‰¤(1+4â¢Kâ¢Î·â¢BÎ¸â¢BÏ†â¢AÏµ)2â¢d.\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}_{\mathrm{lin}}\times\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}}% ,\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty,1}\right)\leq\left(1+\frac{4K\eta B_{\theta}B_% {\varphi}A}{\epsilon}\right)^{2d}\,.caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ ( 1 + divide start_ARG 4 italic_K italic_Î· italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .
Proof.

Let us consider two policies Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ and Ï€â€²superscriptğœ‹â€²\pi^{\prime}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the class Î linsubscriptÎ lin\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. There exist Î¸1,â€¦,Î¸Kâˆˆğ”…â¢(BÎ¸)subscriptğœƒ1â€¦subscriptğœƒğ¾ğ”…subscriptğµğœƒ\theta_{1},\dots,\theta_{K}\in\mathfrak{B}\left(B_{\theta}\right)italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ fraktur_B ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and Î¸1â€²,â€¦,Î¸Kâ€²âˆˆğ”…â¢(BÎ¸)superscriptsubscriptğœƒ1â€²â€¦superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ¾â€²ğ”…subscriptğµğœƒ\theta_{1}^{\prime},\dots,\theta_{K}^{\prime}\in\mathfrak{B}\left(B_{\theta}\right)italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ fraktur_B ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) such that for any state-action pair (x,a)âˆˆğ’³Ã—ğ’œğ‘¥ğ‘ğ’³ğ’œ\left(x,a\right)\in\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}( italic_x , italic_a ) âˆˆ caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_A, Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ and Ï€â€²superscriptğœ‹â€²\pi^{\prime}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be written as

Ï€(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)=expâ¡(Î·â¢âŸ¨Ï†â¢(x,a),âˆ‘k=1KÎ¸kâŸ©)âˆ‘bâˆˆğ’œexpâ¡(Î·â¢âŸ¨Ï†â¢(x,b),âˆ‘k=1KÎ¸kâŸ©),\pi\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)=\frac{% \exp\left(\eta\left\langle{\varphi\left(x,a\right)},{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{k}}% \right\rangle\right)}{\sum_{b\in\mathcal{A}}\exp\left(\eta\left\langle{\varphi% \left(x,b\right)},{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{k}}\right\rangle\right)}\,,italic_Ï€ ( italic_a | italic_x ) = divide start_ARG roman_exp ( italic_Î· âŸ¨ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_a ) , âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_exp ( italic_Î· âŸ¨ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_b ) , âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© ) end_ARG ,

and

Ï€â€²(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)=expâ¡(Î·â¢âŸ¨Ï†â¢(x,a),âˆ‘k=1KÎ¸kâ€²âŸ©)âˆ‘bâˆˆğ’œexpâ¡(Î·â¢âŸ¨Ï†â¢(x,b),âˆ‘k=1KÎ¸kâ€²âŸ©).\pi^{\prime}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right% )=\frac{\exp\left(\eta\left\langle{\varphi\left(x,a\right)},{\sum_{k=1}^{K}% \theta^{\prime}_{k}}\right\rangle\right)}{\sum_{b\in\mathcal{A}}\exp\left(\eta% \left\langle{\varphi\left(x,b\right)},{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\theta^{\prime}_{k}}% \right\rangle\right)}\,.italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_x ) = divide start_ARG roman_exp ( italic_Î· âŸ¨ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_a ) , âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_exp ( italic_Î· âŸ¨ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_b ) , âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© ) end_ARG .

In particular, let us fix a state xâˆˆğ’³ğ‘¥ğ’³x\in\mathcal{X}italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_X, and denote Î¸Â¯K=âˆ‘k=1KÎ¸ksubscriptÂ¯ğœƒğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğœƒğ‘˜\bar{\theta}_{K}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{k}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Î¸Â¯Kâ€²=âˆ‘k=1KÎ¸kâ€²superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğœƒğ¾â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘˜â€²\bar{\theta}_{K}^{\prime}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{k}^{\prime}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. First, by Cauchy-Schwartzâ€™s inequality, we have

âˆ¥Ï€(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ’Ï€â€²(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ¥1â‰¤Aâˆ¥Ï€(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ’Ï€â€²(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ¥.\left\|{\pi\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x% \right)-\pi^{\prime}\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript% \mathpunct{}x\right)}\right\|_{1}\leq\sqrt{A}\left\|{\pi\left(\cdot\nonscript% \mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)-\pi^{\prime}\left(\cdot% \nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}\right\|\,.âˆ¥ italic_Ï€ ( â‹… | italic_x ) - italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( â‹… | italic_x ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ square-root start_ARG italic_A end_ARG âˆ¥ italic_Ï€ ( â‹… | italic_x ) - italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( â‹… | italic_x ) âˆ¥ .

By 1111-Lipshitzness of the softmax function (LemmaÂ 11), it holds that

âˆ¥Ï€(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ’Ï€â€²(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ¥1\displaystyle\left\|{\pi\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript% \mathpunct{}x\right)-\pi^{\prime}\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|% \nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}\right\|_{1}âˆ¥ italic_Ï€ ( â‹… | italic_x ) - italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( â‹… | italic_x ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤Î·â¢Aâ¢â€–âŸ¨Ï†â¢(x,â‹…),Î¸Â¯Kâˆ’Î¸Â¯Kâ€²âŸ©â€–absentğœ‚ğ´normğœ‘ğ‘¥â‹…subscriptÂ¯ğœƒğ¾superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğœƒğ¾â€²\displaystyle\leq\eta\sqrt{A}\left\|{\left\langle\varphi\left(x,\cdot\right),% \bar{\theta}_{K}-\bar{\theta}_{K}^{\prime}\right\rangle}\right\|â‰¤ italic_Î· square-root start_ARG italic_A end_ARG âˆ¥ âŸ¨ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , â‹… ) , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© âˆ¥
=Î·â¢Aâ¢âˆ‘aâˆˆğ’œ(âŸ¨Ï†â¢(x,a),Î¸Â¯Kâˆ’Î¸Â¯Kâ€²âŸ©)2absentğœ‚ğ´subscriptğ‘ğ’œsuperscriptğœ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptÂ¯ğœƒğ¾superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğœƒğ¾â€²2\displaystyle=\eta\sqrt{A\sum_{a\in\mathcal{A}}\left(\left\langle\varphi\left(% x,a\right),\bar{\theta}_{K}-\bar{\theta}_{K}^{\prime}\right\rangle\right)^{2}}= italic_Î· square-root start_ARG italic_A âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( âŸ¨ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_a ) , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG
â‰¤Î·â¢Aâ¢âˆ‘aâˆˆğ’œâ€–Ï†â¢(x,a)â€–2â¢â€–Î¸Â¯Kâˆ’Î¸Â¯Kâ€²â€–2absentğœ‚ğ´subscriptğ‘ğ’œsuperscriptnormğœ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘2superscriptnormsubscriptÂ¯ğœƒğ¾superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğœƒğ¾â€²2\displaystyle\leq\eta\sqrt{A\sum_{a\in\mathcal{A}}\left\|{\varphi\left(x,a% \right)}\right\|^{2}\left\|{\bar{\theta}_{K}-\bar{\theta}_{K}^{\prime}}\right% \|^{2}}â‰¤ italic_Î· square-root start_ARG italic_A âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_a ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG (Cauchy-Schwartz)
â‰¤Î·â¢BÏ†â¢Aâ¢â€–Î¸Â¯Kâˆ’Î¸Â¯Kâ€²â€–absentğœ‚subscriptğµğœ‘ğ´normsubscriptÂ¯ğœƒğ¾superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğœƒğ¾â€²\displaystyle\leq\eta B_{\varphi}A\left\|{\bar{\theta}_{K}-\bar{\theta}_{K}^{% \prime}}\right\|â‰¤ italic_Î· italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A âˆ¥ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ (AssumptionÂ 1)
â‰¤Î·â¢BÏ†â¢Aâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kâ€–Î¸kâˆ’Î¸kâ€²â€–absentğœ‚subscriptğµğœ‘ğ´superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾normsubscriptğœƒğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘˜â€²\displaystyle\leq\eta B_{\varphi}A\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\|{\theta_{k}-\theta_{k}^% {\prime}}\right\|â‰¤ italic_Î· italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ (Triangle inequality)
â‰¤Kâ¢Î·â¢BÏ†â¢Aâ¢maxkâˆˆ[K]â¡â€–Î¸kâˆ’Î¸kâ€²â€–.absentğ¾ğœ‚subscriptğµğœ‘ğ´subscriptğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾normsubscriptğœƒğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘˜â€²\displaystyle\leq K\eta B_{\varphi}A\max_{k\in\left[K\right]}\left\|{\theta_{k% }-\theta_{k}^{\prime}}\right\|\,.â‰¤ italic_K italic_Î· italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ .

Therefore, the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-covering number for Î linsubscriptÎ lin\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respect to the norm âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥1\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ğ’©Ïµ(Î lin,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥1)\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}\right)caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), is upper-bounded by the ÏµKâ¢Î·â¢BÏ†â¢Aitalic-Ïµğ¾ğœ‚subscriptğµğœ‘ğ´\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta B_{\varphi}A}divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_Î· italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG-covering number of the Euclidean ball ğ”…â¢(BÎ¸)ğ”…subscriptğµğœƒ\mathfrak{B}\left(B_{\theta}\right)fraktur_B ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) with respect to the norm âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥\left\|{\cdot}\right\|âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥, and

ğ’©Ïµ(Î lin,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥1)\displaystyle\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}},\left\|{\cdot}% \right\|_{1}\right)caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ğ’©ÏµKâ¢Î·â¢BÏ†â¢A(ğ”…(BÎ¸),âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥)\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{N}_{\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta B_{\varphi}A}}\left(% \mathfrak{B}\left(B_{\theta}\right),\left\|{\cdot}\right\|\right)â‰¤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_Î· italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( fraktur_B ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ )
â‰¤(1+2â¢Kâ¢Î·â¢BÎ¸â¢BÏ†â¢AÏµ)d,absentsuperscript12ğ¾ğœ‚subscriptğµğœƒsubscriptğµğœ‘ğ´italic-Ïµğ‘‘\displaystyle\leq\left(1+\frac{2K\eta B_{\theta}B_{\varphi}A}{\epsilon}\right)% ^{d}\,,â‰¤ ( 1 + divide start_ARG 2 italic_K italic_Î· italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where we used LemmaÂ 12 in the last inequality. For the second part of the lemma, let us consider Q,Qâ€²âˆˆğ’¬linğ‘„superscriptğ‘„â€²subscriptğ’¬linQ,Q^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Q}_{\mathrm{lin}}italic_Q , italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By definition of ğ’¬linsubscriptğ’¬lin\mathcal{Q}_{\mathrm{lin}}caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there exists Î¸,Î¸â€²âˆˆğ”…â¢(BÎ¸)ğœƒsuperscriptğœƒâ€²ğ”…subscriptğµğœƒ\theta,\theta^{\prime}\in\mathfrak{B}\left(B_{\theta}\right)italic_Î¸ , italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ fraktur_B ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) such that for any state-action pair (x,a)ğ‘¥ğ‘\left(x,a\right)( italic_x , italic_a ), Qâ¢(x,a)=âŸ¨Ï†â¢(x,a),Î¸âŸ©ğ‘„ğ‘¥ğ‘ğœ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘ğœƒQ\left(x,a\right)=\left\langle\varphi\left(x,a\right),\theta\right\rangleitalic_Q ( italic_x , italic_a ) = âŸ¨ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_a ) , italic_Î¸ âŸ© and Qâ€²â¢(x,a)=âŸ¨Ï†â¢(x,a),Î¸â€²âŸ©superscriptğ‘„â€²ğ‘¥ğ‘ğœ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘superscriptğœƒâ€²Q^{\prime}\left(x,a\right)=\left\langle\varphi\left(x,a\right),\theta^{\prime}\right\rangleitalic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) = âŸ¨ italic_Ï† ( italic_x , italic_a ) , italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ©. Then,

âˆ

Finally, the following result proves the concentration of the estimators used in AlgorithmÂ 1.

Proof.

Proof.
