B.6 Proof of LemmaÂ 4 (concentration nonlinear case)

Before presenting the proof of TheoremÂ 2, we provide a bound on the covering number of the class ğ’¬Ã—Î ğ’¬ğ’¬subscriptÎ ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}caligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Î ğ’¬subscriptÎ ğ’¬\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is defined in EquationÂ (4). It turns out that the covering number of this class is exponential in Kğ¾Kitalic_K. In the linear case, the exponential dependence in Kğ¾Kitalic_K was avoided because the state-action value class is closed under addition.

Lemma 7 (Covering number of Î ğ’¬subscriptÎ ğ’¬\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT).

It holds that the covering number of the policy class Î ğ’¬subscriptÎ ğ’¬\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be bounded as

ğ’©Ïµ(Î ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥1)â‰¤ğ’©ÏµKâ¢Î·â¢A(ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)K,\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}\right% )\leq\mathcal{N}_{\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta A}}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}% \right\|_{\infty}\right)^{K}\,,caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_Î· italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where, with a slight abuse of notation, âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥1\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the norm defined for any Ï€âˆˆÎ ğ’¬ğœ‹subscriptÎ ğ’¬\pi\in\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}italic_Ï€ âˆˆ roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as âˆ¥Ï€âˆ¥1=supxâˆˆğ’³âˆ¥Ï€(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ¥1\left\|{\pi}\right\|_{1}=\sup_{x\in\mathcal{X}}\left\|{\pi\left(\cdot% \nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}\right\|_{1}âˆ¥ italic_Ï€ âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Ï€ ( â‹… | italic_x ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Moreover,

ğ’©Ïµ(ğ’¬Ã—Î ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ,1)â‰¤ğ’©ÏµKâ¢Î·â¢A(ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)K+1.\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},\left\|{\cdot}% \right\|_{\infty,1}\right)\leq\mathcal{N}_{\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta A}}\left(% \mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty}\right)^{K+1}\,.caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_Î· italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .
Proof.

Let us consider two policies Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ and Ï€â€²superscriptğœ‹â€²\pi^{\prime}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the class Î ğ’¬subscriptÎ ğ’¬\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. There exist Q1,â€¦,QKâˆˆğ’¬subscriptğ‘„1â€¦subscriptğ‘„ğ¾ğ’¬Q_{1},\dots,Q_{K}\in\mathcal{Q}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_Q and Q1â€²,â€¦,QKâ€²âˆˆğ’¬superscriptsubscriptğ‘„1â€²â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ¾â€²ğ’¬Q_{1}^{\prime},\dots,Q_{K}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Q}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_Q such that for any state-action pair (x,a)âˆˆğ’³Ã—ğ’œğ‘¥ğ‘ğ’³ğ’œ\left(x,a\right)\in\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}( italic_x , italic_a ) âˆˆ caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_A, Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ and Ï€â€²superscriptğœ‹â€²\pi^{\prime}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be written as

Ï€(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)=expâ¡(Î·â¢âˆ‘k=1KQkâ¢(x,a))âˆ‘bâˆˆğ’œexpâ¡(Î·â¢âˆ‘k=1KQkâ¢(x,b)),\pi\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)=\frac{% \exp\left(\eta\sum_{k=1}^{K}Q_{k}\left(x,a\right)\right)}{\sum_{b\in\mathcal{A% }}\exp\left(\eta\sum_{k=1}^{K}Q_{k}\left(x,b\right)\right)}\,,italic_Ï€ ( italic_a | italic_x ) = divide start_ARG roman_exp ( italic_Î· âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_exp ( italic_Î· âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_b ) ) end_ARG ,

and

Ï€â€²(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)=expâ¡(Î·â¢âˆ‘k=1KQkâ€²â¢(x,a))âˆ‘bâˆˆğ’œexpâ¡(Î·â¢âˆ‘k=1KQkâ€²â¢(x,b)).\pi^{\prime}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right% )=\frac{\exp\left(\eta\sum_{k=1}^{K}Q_{k}^{\prime}\left(x,a\right)\right)}{% \sum_{b\in\mathcal{A}}\exp\left(\eta\sum_{k=1}^{K}Q_{k}^{\prime}\left(x,b% \right)\right)}\,.italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_x ) = divide start_ARG roman_exp ( italic_Î· âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_exp ( italic_Î· âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_b ) ) end_ARG .

Let xâˆˆğ’³ğ‘¥ğ’³x\in\mathcal{X}italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_X. Using âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥1â‰¤Aâˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}\leq\sqrt{A}\left\|{\cdot}\right\|âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ square-root start_ARG italic_A end_ARG âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ in â„Asuperscriptâ„ğ´\mathbb{R}^{A}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and by 1111-Lipshitzness of the softmax function (LemmaÂ 11), it holds that

âˆ¥Ï€(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ’Ï€â€²(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ¥1\displaystyle\left\|{\pi\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript% \mathpunct{}x\right)-\pi^{\prime}\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|% \nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}\right\|_{1}âˆ¥ italic_Ï€ ( â‹… | italic_x ) - italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( â‹… | italic_x ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤Aâˆ¥Ï€(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ’Ï€â€²(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ¥\displaystyle\leq\sqrt{A}\left\|{\pi\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|% \nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)-\pi^{\prime}\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{}% \middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}\right\|â‰¤ square-root start_ARG italic_A end_ARG âˆ¥ italic_Ï€ ( â‹… | italic_x ) - italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( â‹… | italic_x ) âˆ¥
â‰¤Î·â¢Aâ¢â€–âˆ‘k=1K(Qkâ¢(x,â‹…)âˆ’Qkâ€²â¢(x,â‹…))â€–absentğœ‚ğ´normsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜ğ‘¥â‹…superscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜â€²ğ‘¥â‹…\displaystyle\leq\eta\sqrt{A}\left\|{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(Q_{k}\left(x,\cdot% \right)-Q_{k}^{\prime}\left(x,\cdot\right)\right)}\right\|â‰¤ italic_Î· square-root start_ARG italic_A end_ARG âˆ¥ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , â‹… ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , â‹… ) ) âˆ¥
â‰¤Î·â¢Aâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kâ€–Qkâ¢(x,â‹…)âˆ’Qkâ€²â¢(x,â‹…)â€–absentğœ‚ğ´superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾normsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜ğ‘¥â‹…superscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜â€²ğ‘¥â‹…\displaystyle\leq\eta\sqrt{A}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\|{Q_{k}\left(x,\cdot\right)-Q% _{k}^{\prime}\left(x,\cdot\right)}\right\|â‰¤ italic_Î· square-root start_ARG italic_A end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , â‹… ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , â‹… ) âˆ¥ (Triangle inequality)
â‰¤Î·â¢Aâ¢âˆ‘k=1Ksupaâˆˆğ’œ|Qkâ¢(x,a)âˆ’Qkâ€²â¢(x,a)|absentğœ‚ğ´superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptsupremumğ‘ğ’œsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜ğ‘¥ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜â€²ğ‘¥ğ‘\displaystyle\leq\eta A\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sup_{a\in\mathcal{A}}\left|{Q_{k}\left(x% ,a\right)-Q_{k}^{\prime}\left(x,a\right)}\right|â‰¤ italic_Î· italic_A âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) | (âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥â‰¤Aâˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)\displaystyle(\left\|{\cdot}\right\|\leq\sqrt{A}\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty})( âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ â‰¤ square-root start_ARG italic_A end_ARG âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
â‰¤Î·â¢Aâ¢supxâˆˆğ’³{âˆ‘k=1Ksupaâˆˆğ’œ|Qkâ¢(x,a)âˆ’Qkâ€²â¢(x,a)|}absentğœ‚ğ´subscriptsupremumğ‘¥ğ’³superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptsupremumğ‘ğ’œsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜ğ‘¥ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜â€²ğ‘¥ğ‘\displaystyle\leq\eta A\sup_{x\in\mathcal{X}}\left\{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sup_{a\in% \mathcal{A}}\left|{Q_{k}\left(x,a\right)-Q_{k}^{\prime}\left(x,a\right)}\right% |\right\}â‰¤ italic_Î· italic_A roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) | }
â‰¤Î·â¢Aâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kâ€–Qkâˆ’Qkâ€²â€–âˆabsentğœ‚ğ´superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜â€²\displaystyle\leq\eta A\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\|{Q_{k}-Q_{k}^{\prime}}\right\|_{\infty}â‰¤ italic_Î· italic_A âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Triangle inequality).(Triangle inequality)\displaystyle\text{(Triangle inequality)}\,.(Triangle inequality) .

In particular, this implies

maxxâˆˆğ’³âˆ¥Ï€(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ’Ï€â€²(â‹…\nonscript|\nonscriptx)âˆ¥1â‰¤Î·Aâˆ‘k=1Kâˆ¥Qkâ€²âˆ’Qkâˆ¥âˆ.\displaystyle\max_{x\in\mathcal{X}}\left\|{\pi\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{% }\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)-\pi^{\prime}\left(\cdot\nonscript% \mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}\right\|_{1}\leq\eta A\sum_% {k=1}^{K}\left\|{Q_{k}^{\prime}-Q_{k}}\right\|_{\infty}\,.roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Ï€ ( â‹… | italic_x ) - italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( â‹… | italic_x ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Î· italic_A âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Thus, the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-covering number for Î ğ’¬subscriptÎ ğ’¬\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ğ’©Ïµ(Î ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥1)\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}\right)caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), is upper-bounded by the ÏµKâ¢Î·â¢Aitalic-Ïµğ¾ğœ‚ğ´\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta A}divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_Î· italic_A end_ARG-covering number of the class ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q to the power Kğ¾Kitalic_K, i.e., ğ’©ÏµKâ¢Î·â¢A(ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)K\mathcal{N}_{\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta A}}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|% _{\infty}\right)^{K}caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_Î· italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Thus,

ğ’©Ïµ(Î ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥1)â‰¤ğ’©ÏµKâ¢Î·â¢A(ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)K.\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}\right% )\leq\mathcal{N}_{\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta A}}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}% \right\|_{\infty}\right)^{K}\,.caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_Î· italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

The proof is concluded by noting that the covering number increases with the precision (when Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ decreases), and therefore, we can write

ğ’©Ïµ(ğ’¬Ã—Î ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ,1)\displaystyle\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},% \left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty,1}\right)caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ğ’©Ïµ/2(ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)ğ’©Ïµ/2(Î ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥1)\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon/2}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}% \right\|_{\infty}\right)\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon/2}\left(\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},\left% \|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}\right)â‰¤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
â‰¤ğ’©Ïµ/2(ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)ğ’©ÏµKâ¢Î·â¢A(ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)K\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon/2}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}% \right\|_{\infty}\right)\mathcal{N}_{\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta A}}\left(\mathcal{Q% },\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty}\right)^{K}â‰¤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_Î· italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
â‰¤ğ’©ÏµKâ¢Î·â¢A(ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)K+1.\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{N}_{\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta A}}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left% \|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty}\right)^{K+1}\,.â‰¤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_Î· italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

âˆ

Finally, the following result proves the concentration of the estimators used in AlgorithmÂ 2.

Lemma 8.

Let {Ï€k}kâˆˆ[K]subscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾\left\{\pi_{k}\right\}_{k\in\left[K\right]}{ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the sequence of policies generated by AlgorithmÂ 2. Then, with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´, for any kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in\left[K\right]italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ], it holds that

supQâˆˆğ’¬|â„’^â¢(Ï€k,Q)âˆ’â„’â¢(Ï€k,Q)|â‰¤12â¢K+2(K+1)log(2ğ’©(1âˆ’Î³)/8â¢K(ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)/Î´)(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Ï„E.\sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}}\left|{\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k},Q\right)-% \mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k},Q\right)}\right|\leq\frac{1}{2K}+\sqrt{\frac{2\left(K% +1\right)\log\left(2\mathcal{N}_{\left(1-\gamma\right)/8K}\left(\mathcal{Q},% \left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty}\right)/\delta\right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2% }\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\,.roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) - caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) | â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_K + 1 ) roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) / 8 italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_Î´ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG .
Proof.

Note that by construction, the policy sequence {Ï€k}kâˆˆ[K]subscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾\left\{\pi_{k}\right\}_{k\in\left[K\right]}{ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT generated by AlgorithmÂ 2 belongs to the policy class Î ğ’¬subscriptÎ ğ’¬\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, invoking LemmaÂ 5, we have that with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´, for any kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in\left[K\right]italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ], it holds that

Î”â¢(Ï€k)â‰¤infÏµ:Ïµ>0{4â¢Ïµ1âˆ’Î³+2log(2ğ’©Ïµ(ğ’¬Ã—Î ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ,1)/Î´)(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Ï„E}.\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)\leq\inf_{\epsilon:\epsilon>0}\left\{\frac{4\epsilon% }{1-\gamma}+\sqrt{\frac{2\log\left(2\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}% \times\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty,1}\right)/\delta\right)% }{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\right\}\,.roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ : italic_Ïµ > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { divide start_ARG 4 italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Î³ end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_Î´ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG } .

Therefore, choosing Ïµ=1âˆ’Î³8â¢Kitalic-Ïµ1ğ›¾8ğ¾\epsilon=\frac{1-\gamma}{8K}italic_Ïµ = divide start_ARG 1 - italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG 8 italic_K end_ARG, we get

Î”â¢(Ï€k)Î”subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\displaystyle\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤12â¢K+2log(2ğ’©(1âˆ’Î³)/8â¢K(ğ’¬Ã—Î ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ,1)/Î´)(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Ï„E\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{2K}+\sqrt{\frac{2\log\left(2\mathcal{N}_{\left(1-% \gamma\right)/8K}\left(\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},\left\|{\cdot}\right% \|_{\infty,1}\right)/\delta\right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) / 8 italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q Ã— roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_Î´ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG
â‰¤12â¢K+2(K+1)log(2ğ’©1âˆ’Î³8â¢K2â¢Î·â¢A(ğ’¬,âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ)/Î´)(1âˆ’Î³)2â¢Ï„E.\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{2K}+\sqrt{\frac{2\left(K+1\right)\log\left(2\mathcal% {N}_{\frac{1-\gamma}{8K^{2}\eta A}}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{% \infty}\right)/\delta\right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\,.â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_K + 1 ) roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 - italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG 8 italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_Î´ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG .

âˆ

B.7 Proof of TheoremÂ 2 (sample complexity guarantee for QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable MDPs)

We are now ready for the proof of TheoremÂ 2, which we restate for convenience.

See 2

Proof.

Recall that by PropositionÂ 1, we have

ğ”¼â¢[ÏÏ€Eâˆ’ÏÏ€out]â‰¤1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ”¼â¢[â„’â¢(Ï€k;Qk)]+2Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ”¼â¢[Î”â¢(Ï€k)].ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğœŒsubscriptğœ‹EsuperscriptğœŒsuperscriptğœ‹out1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜2ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]Î”subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\mathbb{E}\left[\rho^{{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}-\rho^{\pi^{\mathrm% {out}}}\right]\leq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\mathcal{L}\left(% \pi_{k};Q_{k}\right)\right]+\frac{2}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta% \left(\pi_{k}\right)\right]\,.blackboard_E [ italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] + divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_Î” ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] .

Then, by LemmaÂ 2, it holds that

1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ”¼â¢[â„’â¢(Ï€k;Qk)]â‰¤logâ¡(A)Î·â¢K+Î·(1âˆ’Î³)2.1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]â„’subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜ğ´ğœ‚ğ¾ğœ‚superscript1ğ›¾2\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k};Q_{k}\right)% \right]\leq\frac{\log\left(A\right)}{\eta K}+\frac{\eta}{\left(1-\gamma\right)% ^{2}}\,.divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ caligraphic_L ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG roman_log ( italic_A ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· italic_K end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î³ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG .

Appendix C Technical tools

Lemma 9 (Hoeffdingâ€™s inequality).

Let X1,â€¦,Xnsubscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be independent random variables such that |Xi|â‰¤Msubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘€\left|{X_{i}}\right|\leq M| italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¤ italic_M for all iğ‘–iitalic_i. Then, for any Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0,

â„™â¢(|1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’ğ”¼â¢(Xi))|>Ïµ)â‰¤2â¢eâˆ’2â¢nâ¢Ïµ2M2.â„™1ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘›ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ”¼subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–italic-Ïµ2superscriptğ‘’2ğ‘›superscriptitalic-Ïµ2superscriptğ‘€2\mathbb{P}\left(\left|{\frac{1}{n}\sum^{n}_{i=1}\left(X_{i}-\mathbb{E}\left(X_% {i}\right)\right)}\right|>\epsilon\right)\leq 2e^{-\frac{2n\epsilon^{2}}{M^{2}% }}\,.blackboard_P ( | divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - blackboard_E ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) | > italic_Ïµ ) â‰¤ 2 italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 2 italic_n italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .
Lemma 10 (Simplified version of Orabona, 2023, TheoremÂ 6.10).

Let us consider a non-empty closed convex set Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V, an arbitrary sequence of adaptively chosen loss vectors (â„“k)k=1Ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptâ„“ğ‘˜ğ¾ğ‘˜1\left(\ell_{k}\right)^{K}_{k=1}( roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that â€–â„“kâ€–âˆâ‰¤â„“maxsubscriptnormsubscriptâ„“ğ‘˜subscriptâ„“\left\|{\ell_{k}}\right\|_{\infty}\leq\ell_{\max}âˆ¥ roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and let D:VÃ—intâ¢(V)â†’â„:ğ·â†’ğ‘‰intğ‘‰â„D:V\times\mathrm{int}\left(V\right)\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_D : italic_V Ã— roman_int ( italic_V ) â†’ blackboard_R be a Bregman divergence induced by a Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î»-strongly convex function in the â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm. Then, for all uâˆˆVğ‘¢ğ‘‰u\in Vitalic_u âˆˆ italic_V, the sequence (xk)k=1Ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ¾ğ‘˜1\left(x_{k}\right)^{K}_{k=1}( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT generated for any kğ‘˜kitalic_k as

for an arbitrary initial x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies

Lemma 11 (Gao and Pavel, 2017, PropositionÂ 4).

Lemma 12 (Covering number of a Euclidean ball).

Appendix D On the guarantees of misspecified BC in linear QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable MDPs

It is natural to question whether existing bounds for behavioral cloning (BC) in misspecified settings [e.g., Rohatgi etÂ al., 2025, Foster etÂ al., 2024] offer satisfactory sample complexity guarantees for imitating an arbitrarily complex expert within a linear QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable MDP. This section presents a negative result, demonstrating that the approximation error incurred by BC, when restricted to a linear softmax policy class (denoted Î linsubscriptÎ lin\Pi_{\text{lin}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), can be large even in a simple linear QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable MDP.

Consider a single-state MDP defined as follows. Let Aâˆˆâ„•âˆ—ğ´superscriptâ„•A\in\mathbb{N}^{*}italic_A âˆˆ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the number of actions, with the action space ğ’œ=[[1,â€¦,A]]ğ’œdelimited-[]1â€¦ğ´\mathcal{A}=\left[\![1,\dots,A\right]\!]caligraphic_A = [ [ 1 , â€¦ , italic_A ] ]. For each action aâˆˆğ’œğ‘ğ’œa\in\mathcal{A}italic_a âˆˆ caligraphic_A, there is a scalar feature Ï†â¢(a)=âˆ’A2+aâˆˆâ„ğœ‘ğ‘ğ´2ğ‘â„\varphi\left(a\right)=-\frac{A}{2}+a\in\mathbb{R}italic_Ï† ( italic_a ) = - divide start_ARG italic_A end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + italic_a âˆˆ blackboard_R. To ensure the MDP is linear QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable, the true reward function is rtrueâ¢(a)=Î¶â¢Ï†â¢(a)subscriptğ‘Ÿtrueğ‘ğœğœ‘ğ‘r_{\text{true}}\left(a\right)=\zeta\varphi\left(a\right)italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT true end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a ) = italic_Î¶ italic_Ï† ( italic_a ) for some parameter Î¶âˆˆâ„ğœâ„\zeta\in\mathbb{R}italic_Î¶ âˆˆ blackboard_R unknown to the learner. We define a softmax quadratic expert policy Ï€Esubscriptğœ‹E{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as

Ï€Eâ¢(a)=expâ¡(Ï†â¢(a)2)âˆ‘bâˆˆğ’œexpâ¡(Ï†â¢(b)2).subscriptğœ‹Eğ‘ğœ‘superscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘ğ’œğœ‘superscriptğ‘2{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\left(a\right)=\frac{\exp\left(\varphi% \left(a\right)^{2}\right)}{\sum_{b\in\mathcal{A}}\exp\left(\varphi\left(b% \right)^{2}\right)}\,.italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a ) = divide start_ARG roman_exp ( italic_Ï† ( italic_a ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_exp ( italic_Ï† ( italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG .

This expert policy assigns the highest probability to extremal actions (i.e., a=1ğ‘1a=1italic_a = 1 and a=Ağ‘ğ´a=Aitalic_a = italic_A). In contrast, linear softmax policies Ï€âˆˆÎ linğœ‹subscriptÎ lin\pi\in\Pi_{\text{lin}}italic_Ï€ âˆˆ roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (which are commonly used for BC in feature-based settings) are inherently designed to produce monotonic probability distributions over the action space when features are ordered (i.e., for actions a,aâ€²âˆˆğ’œğ‘superscriptğ‘â€²ğ’œa,a^{\prime}\in\mathcal{A}italic_a , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_A with aâ€²>asuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘a^{\prime}>aitalic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > italic_a, either Ï€â¢(a)â‰¤Ï€â¢(aâ€²)ğœ‹ğ‘ğœ‹superscriptğ‘â€²\pi\left(a\right)\leq\pi\left(a^{\prime}\right)italic_Ï€ ( italic_a ) â‰¤ italic_Ï€ ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) or Ï€â¢(a)â‰¥Ï€â¢(aâ€²)ğœ‹ğ‘ğœ‹superscriptğ‘â€²\pi\left(a\right)\geq\pi\left(a^{\prime}\right)italic_Ï€ ( italic_a ) â‰¥ italic_Ï€ ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )). Consequently, for A>2ğ´2A>2italic_A > 2, no policy in Î linsubscriptÎ lin\Pi_{\text{lin}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can achieve a small Hellinger distance to this softmax quadratic expert. We illustrate this in FigureÂ 3, where we compare the softmax quadratic expert with two linear softmax policies. Due to the monotonicity constraint, the linear softmax policies are unable to approximate the expert policy everywhere.

It remains an open question whether behavioral cloning analyses can be refined to better leverage the underlying MDP structure in such misspecified scenarios. Specifically, for the constructed example, it would be advantageous if the misspecification error in existing bounds were characterized in terms of feature expectations (e.g., âˆ‘aâˆˆğ’œÏ€â¢(a)â¢Ï†â¢(a)subscriptğ‘ğ’œğœ‹ğ‘ğœ‘ğ‘\sum_{a\in\mathcal{A}}\pi\left(a\right)\varphi\left(a\right)âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a âˆˆ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ ( italic_a ) italic_Ï† ( italic_a )) rather than state-action distributions.

Appendix E Experimental details

For the first experiment shown in FigureÂ 1, one may wonder if the underperformance of behavioural cloning might be due to underoptimizing the empirical log-likehood. We have ruled out this possibility by going into great lengths to optimize the likelihood, and in fact the log-likelihood has approached its minimum value of zero very closely in our experiment (meaning that the probability assigned to the actions seen in the expert dataset is almost 1111). For this optimization task, we have used Adam with default parameter settings. For the experiments in FigureÂ 2, algorithms are implemented using a shared neural network architecture consisting of 3 layers with 64 neurons per layer. This architecture matches the one used for experiments in the same environments by Garg etÂ al. [2021]. For behavioral cloning, we employ a separate three-layer multilayer perceptron with 128 neurons per layer. Implementations of IQ-Learn and P2IL utilize their original hyperparameter configurations as reported in their respective publications. All networks are optimized using the Adam optimizer [Kingma and Ba, 2014] with a learning rate of 5Ã—10âˆ’35superscript1035\times 10^{-3}5 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and default momentum parameters (Î²1=0.9,Î²2=0.999formulae-sequencesubscriptğ›½10.9subscriptğ›½20.999\beta_{1}=0.9,\beta_{2}=0.999italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.9 , italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.999). The implementations are built using PyTorch [Paszke, 2019].

For algorithms with a primal-dual structure (i.e., IQ-Learn, P2IL, and SPOIL), the policy update is performed using a Softâ€‰DQN-style update [cf. Haarnoja etÂ al., 2017] with a fixed temperature parameter. These three algorithms thus only differ in terms of their Q-value updates, and thus this experiment serves to assess the effectiveness of the novel critic loss introduced in this work.

Appendix F Future directions

Possible improvements.

The most interesting immediate question that one can ask about our result is if the ğ’ªâ¢(Îµâˆ’4)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ€4\mathcal{O}\left(\varepsilon^{-4}\right)caligraphic_O ( italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) scaling featured in our general bound is improvable under the conditions we assume. We believe that substantially different algorithmic and analytic ideas would be necessary to answer this question, but we also think that our primal-dual framework provides a good starting point towards making such improvements. Furthermore, we would be curious to investigate appropriate notions of misspecification that our algorithm can deal with. It can be easily shown that requiring QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizability only up to a worst-case additive error of order Îµapproxsubscriptğœ€approx\varepsilon_{\text{approx}}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT approx end_POSTSUBSCRIPT would incur the same additional term in the error bounds, but we believe that this assumption is too strong to warrant interest and we did not include an explicit statement. A much more interesting question is if this approximation guarantee would only be required to hold locally in the state-action pairs visited by the expert, or only for specific policies (most ideally only the expert policy). Given the numerous negative results in RL theory about such weaker function approximators, we are not optimistic that these latter improvements are possible, but nevertheless (and once again), we feel that our analytic framework can provide suitable tools for analyzing such questions.

Learning from features only.

In the case of linear function approximation, the current approach critically relies on observing the expert state-action pairs to compute the vectors {g^k}k=1Ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘”ğ‘˜ğ¾ğ‘˜1\left\{\widehat{g}_{k}\right\}^{K}_{k=1}{ over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It would be interesting to check if an alternative algorithm can achieve the same guarantees by only observing the feature vectors instead. In other words, the design of an algorithm taking as input a dataset {Ï†â¢(XEi,AEi)}i=1Ï„Esubscriptsuperscriptğœ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹Eğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ´Eğ‘–subscriptğœEğ‘–1\left\{\varphi\left(X_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i},A_{\scriptscriptstyle% \textup{E}}^{i}\right)\right\}^{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}_{i=1}{ italic_Ï† ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an interesting open problem.

New efficient algorithms that learn state-action value functions from expert data.

Despite having proven successful in practice [Garg etÂ al., 2021], the idea of learning a state-action value function from expert data without passing through a learned reward function has not been used to develop theoretically grounded algorithms. Our work is the first example of an algorithm enjoying theoretical guarantees applying this principle. We expect this principle to find other applications in imitation learning theory, for example on the open problem of learning to imitate an expert from state-only trajectory given trajectory access to a linear-QÏ€superscriptğ‘„ğœ‹Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT realizable MDP.
